div.head: Act 1, Scene 1
div.stage: Enter JUSTICE SHALLOW, SLENDER, and SIR HUGH EVANS.

sp.speaker: Shallow
sp.ab: Sir Hugh, persuade me not; I will make a Star
chamber matter of it: if he were twenty Sir John
Falstaffs, he shall not abuse Robert Shallow, esquire.

sp.speaker: Slender
sp.ab: In the county of Gloucester, justice of peace and
“Coram.”

sp.speaker: Shallow
sp.ab: Ay, cousin Slender, and “Custalorum.”

sp.speaker: Slender
sp.ab: Ay, and “Rato-lorum” too; and a gentleman born,
master parson; who writes himself “Armigero,” in
any bill, warrant, quittance, or obligation,
“Armigero.”

sp.speaker: Shallow
sp.ab: Ay, that I do; and have done any time these three
hundred years.

sp.speaker: Slender
sp.ab: All his successors gone before him hath done't;
and all his ancestors that come after him may: they
may give the dozen white luces in their coat.

sp.speaker: Shallow
sp.ab: It is an old coat.

sp.speaker: Evans
sp.ab: The dozen white louses do become an old coat
well; it agrees well, passant; it is a familiar beast
to man, and signifies love.

sp.speaker: Shallow
sp.ab: The luce is the fresh fish; the salt fish is an old
coat.

sp.speaker: Slender
sp.ab: I may quarter, coz.

sp.speaker: Shallow
sp.ab: You may, by marrying.

sp.speaker: Evans
sp.ab: It is marring indeed, if he quarter it.

sp.speaker: Shallow
sp.ab: Not a whit.

sp.speaker: Evans
sp.ab: Yes, py'r lady; if he has a quarter of your coat,
there is but three skirts for yourself, in my
simple conjectures: but that is all one. If Sir
John Falstaff have committed disparagements unto
you, I am of the church, and will be glad to do
my benevolence to make atonements and compremises
between you.

sp.speaker: Shallow
sp.ab: The council shall hear it; it is a riot.

sp.speaker: Evans
sp.ab: It is not meet the council hear a riot; there is
no fear of Got in a riot: the council, look you,
shall desire to hear the fear of Got, and not to hear
a riot; take your vizaments in that.

sp.speaker: Shallow
sp.ab: Ha! o' my life, if I were young again, the sword
should end it.

sp.speaker: Evans
sp.ab: It is petter that friends is the sword, and end
it: and there is also another device in my prain,
which peradventure prings goot discretions with
it: there is Anne Page, which is daughter to Master
George Page, which is pretty virginity.

sp.speaker: Slender
sp.ab: Mistress Anne Page? She has brown hair, and speaks
small like a woman.

sp.speaker: Evans
sp.ab: It is that fery person for all the 'orld, as just
as you will desire; and seven hundred pounds of
moneys, and gold and silver, is her grandsire
upon his death's-bed — Got deliver to a joyful
resurrections! — give, when she is able to overtake
seventeen years old: it were a goot motion if we
leave our pribbles and prabbles, and desire a
marriage between Master Abraham and Mistress Anne
Page.

sp.speaker: Slender
sp.ab: Did her grandsire leave her seven hundred pound?

sp.speaker: Evans
sp.ab: Ay, and her father is make her a petter penny.

sp.speaker: Slender
sp.ab: I know the young gentlewoman; she has good gifts.

sp.speaker: Evans
sp.ab: Seven hundred pounds and possibilities is goot gifts.

sp.speaker: Shallow
sp.ab: Well, let us see honest Master Page. Is Falstaff
there?

sp.speaker: Evans
sp.ab: Shall I tell you a lie? I do despise a liar as
I do despise one that is false, or as I despise
one that is not true. The knight, Sir John, is
there; and, I beseech you, be ruled by your
well-willers. I will peat the door for Master Page.
What ho! Got pless your house here!

sp.speaker: Page
sp.ab: Who's there!

sp.speaker: Evans
sp.ab: Here is Got's plessing, and your friend, and
Justice Shallow; and here young Master Slender,
that peradventures shall tell you another tale, if
matters grow to your likings.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.ab: I am glad to see your worships well. I thank you for
my venison, Master Shallow.

sp.speaker: Shallow
sp.ab: Master Page, I am glad to see you: much good do
it your good heart! I wished your venison better;
it was ill killed. How doth good Mistress Page? — and I
thank you always with my heart, la! with my heart.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.ab: Sir, I thank you.

sp.speaker: Shallow
sp.ab: Sir, I thank you; by yea and no, I do.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.ab: I am glad to see you, good Master Slender.

sp.speaker: Slender
sp.ab: How does your fallow greyhound, sir? I heard say he
was outrun on Cotsall.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.ab: It could not be judged, sir.

sp.speaker: Slender
sp.ab: You'll not confess, you'll not confess.

sp.speaker: Shallow
sp.ab: That he will not. 'Tis your fault, 'tis your fault;
'tis a good dog.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.ab: A cur, sir.

sp.speaker: Shallow
sp.ab: Sir, he's a good dog, and a fair dog: can there
be more said? he is good and fair. Is Sir John
Falstaff here?

sp.speaker: Page
sp.ab: Sir, he is within; and I would I could do a good
office between you.

sp.speaker: Evans
sp.ab: It is spoke as a Christians ought to speak.

sp.speaker: Shallow
sp.ab: He hath wronged me, Master Page.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.ab: Sir, he doth in some sort confess it.

sp.speaker: Shallow
sp.ab: If it be confessed, it is not redressed: is not
that so, Master Page? He hath wronged me; indeed
he hath; at a word, he hath, believe me: Robert
Shallow, esquire, saith, he is wronged.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.ab: Here comes Sir John.
sp.stage: Enter SIR JOHN FALSTAFF, BARDOLPH, NYM and PISTOL.

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: Now, Master Shallow, you'll complain of me to the
king?

sp.speaker: Shallow
sp.ab: Knight, you have beaten my men, killed my deer, and
broke open my lodge.

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: But not kissed your keeper's daughter?

sp.speaker: Shallow
sp.ab: Tut, a pin! this shall be answered.

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: I will answer it straight, I have done all this. That
is now answered.

sp.speaker: Shallow
sp.ab: The council shall know this.

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: 'Twere better for you if it were known in counsel:
you'll be laughed at.

sp.speaker: Evans
sp.ab: Pauca verba, Sir John; good worts.

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: Good worts! good cabbage. Slender, I broke your head:
what matter have you against me?

sp.speaker: Slender
sp.ab: Marry, sir, I have matter in my head against you;
and against your cony-catching rascals, Bardolph,
Nym, and Pistol. They carried me to the tavern and
made me drunk, and afterward picked my pocket.

sp.speaker: Bardolph
sp.ab: You Banbury cheese!

sp.speaker: Slender
sp.ab: Ay, it is no matter.

sp.speaker: Pistol
sp.ab: How now, Mephostophilus!

sp.speaker: Slender
sp.ab: Ay, it is no matter.

sp.speaker: Nym
sp.ab: Slice, I say! pauca, pauca: slice! that's my humour.

sp.speaker: Slender
sp.ab: Where's Simple, my man? Can you tell, cousin?

sp.speaker: Evans
sp.ab: Peace, I pray you. Now let us understand. There
is three umpires in this matter, as I understand;
that is, Master Page, fidelicet Master Page; and
there is myself, fidelicet myself; and the three party
is, lastly and finally, mine host of the Garter.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.ab: We three, to hear it and end it between them.

sp.speaker: Evans
sp.ab: Fery goot: I will make a prief of it in my
note-book; and we will afterwards ork upon the cause
with as great discreetly as we can.

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: Pistol!

sp.speaker: Pistol
sp.ab: He hears with ears.

sp.speaker: Evans
sp.ab: The tevil and his tam! what phrase is this, “He hears
with ear”? why, it is affectations.

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: Pistol, did you pick Master Slender's purse?

sp.speaker: Slender
sp.ab: Ay, by these gloves, did he, or I would I might
never come in mine own great chamber again else,
of seven groats in mill-sixpences, and two Edward
shovel-boards, that cost me two shilling and two pence
a-piece of Yead Miller, by these gloves.

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: Is this true, Pistol?

sp.speaker: Evans
sp.ab: No; it is false, if it is a pickpurse.

sp.speaker: Pistol
sp.l: Ha, thou mountain-foreigner! Sir John and master mine,
I combat challenge of this latten bilbo.
Word of denial in thy labras here!
Word of denial; froth and scum, thou liest!

sp.speaker: Slender
sp.ab: By these gloves, then, 'twas he.

sp.speaker: Nym
sp.ab: Be avised, sir, and pass good humours: I will
say “marry trap” with you, if you run the nuthook's
humour on me; that is the very note of it.

sp.speaker: Slender
sp.ab: By this hat, then, he in the red face had it;
for though I cannot remember what I did when you made
me drunk, yet I am not altogether an ass.

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: What say you, Scarlet and John?

sp.speaker: Bardolph
sp.ab: Why, sir, for my part, I say the gentleman had drunk
himself out of his five sentences.

sp.speaker: Evans
sp.ab: It is his five senses: fie, what the ignorance is!

sp.speaker: Bardolph
sp.ab: And being fap, sir, was, as they say, cashiered; and
so conclusions passed the careers.

sp.speaker: Slender
sp.ab: Ay, you spake in Latin then too; but 'tis no
matter: I'll ne'er be drunk whilst I live again,
but in honest, civil, godly company, for this
trick: if I be drunk, I'll be drunk with those
that have the fear of God, and not with drunken
knaves.

sp.speaker: Evans
sp.ab: So Got udge me, that is a virtuous mind.

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: You hear all these matters denied, gentlemen; you hear
it.
sp.stage: Enter ANNE PACE, with wine; MISTRESS FORD and MISTRESS PAGE, following.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.ab: Nay, daughter, carry the wine in; we'll drink within.

sp.speaker: Slender
sp.ab: O heaven! this is Mistress Anne Page.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.ab: How now, Mistress Ford!

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: Mistress Ford, by my troth, you are very well met: by
your leave, good mistress.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.ab: Wife, bid these gentlemen welcome: Come, we have
a hot venison pasty to dinner: come, gentlemen, I hope
we shall drink down all unkindness.
sp.stage: Exeunt all except Shal., Slen., and Evans.

sp.speaker: Slender
sp.ab: I had rather than forty shillings I had my Book
of Songs and Sonnets here.
How now, Simple! where have you been? I must wait
on myself, must I? You have not the Book of Riddles
about you, have you?

sp.speaker: Simple
sp.ab: Book of Riddles! why, did you not lend it to
Alice Shortcake upon All-hallowmas last, a fortnight
afore Michaelmas?

sp.speaker: Shallow
sp.ab: Come, coz; come, coz; we stay for you. A word
with you, coz; marry, this, coz: there is, as
'twere, a tender, a kind of tender, made afar off by
Sir Hugh here. Do you understand me?

sp.speaker: Slender
sp.ab: Ay, sir, you shall find me reasonable; if it be so, I
shall do that that is reason.

sp.speaker: Shallow
sp.ab: Nay, but understand me.

sp.speaker: Slender
sp.ab: So I do, sir.

sp.speaker: Evans
sp.ab: Give ear to his motions, Master Slender: I will
description the matter to you, if you be capacity of
it.

sp.speaker: Slender
sp.ab: Nay, I will do as my cousin Shallow says: I pray
you, pardon me; he's a justice of peace in his
country, simple though I stand here.

sp.speaker: Evans
sp.ab: But that is not the question: the question is
concerning your marriage.

sp.speaker: Shallow
sp.ab: Ay, there's the point, sir.

sp.speaker: Evans
sp.ab: Marry, is it; the very point of it; to Mistress Anne
Page.

sp.speaker: Slender
sp.ab: Why, if it be so, I will marry her upon any reasonable
demands.

sp.speaker: Evans
sp.ab: But can you affection the 'oman? Let us command
to know that of your mouth or of your lips; for
divers philosophers hold that the lips is parcel
of the mouth. Therefore, precisely, can you carry your
good will to the maid?

sp.speaker: Shallow
sp.ab: Cousin Abraham Slender, can you love her?

sp.speaker: Slender
sp.ab: I hope, sir, I will do as it shall become one that
would do reason.

sp.speaker: Evans
sp.ab: Nay, Got's lords and his ladies! you must speak
possitable, if you can carry her your desires towards
her.

sp.speaker: Shallow
sp.ab: That you must. Will you, upon good dowry, marry her?

sp.speaker: Slender
sp.ab: I will do a greater thing than that, upon your
request, cousin, in any reason.

sp.speaker: Shallow
sp.ab: Nay, conceive me, conceive me, sweet coz: what
I do is to pleasure you, coz. Can you love the maid?

sp.speaker: Slender
sp.ab: I will marry her, sir, at your request: but if
there be no great love in the beginning, yet
heaven may decrease it upon better acquaintance,
when we are married and have more occasion to
know one another; I hope, upon familiarity will
grow more content: but if you say, “Marry her,”
I will marry her; that I am freely dissolved, and
dissolutely.

sp.speaker: Evans
sp.ab: It is a fery discretion answer; save the fall is
in the ort “dissolutely:” the ort is, according to our
meaning, “resolutely:” his meaning is good.

sp.speaker: Shallow
sp.ab: Ay, I think my cousin meant well.

sp.speaker: Slender
sp.ab: Ay, or else I would I might be hanged, la!

sp.speaker: Shallow
sp.ab: Here comes fair Mistress Anne.
Would I were young for your sake, Mistress Anne!

sp.speaker: Anne
sp.ab: The dinner is on the table; my father desires your
worships' company.

sp.speaker: Shallow
sp.ab: I will wait on him, fair Mistress Anne.

sp.speaker: Evans
sp.ab: 'Od's plessed will! I will not be absence at the
grace.

sp.speaker: Anne
sp.ab: Will't please your worship to come in, sir?

sp.speaker: Slender
sp.ab: No, I thank you, forsooth, heartily; I am very well.

sp.speaker: Anne
sp.ab: The dinner attends you, sir.

sp.speaker: Slender
sp.ab: I am not a-hungry, I thank you, forsooth. Go,
sirrah, for all you are my man, go wait upon my
cousin Shallow.
A justice of peace sometime may be beholding to
his friend for a man. I keep but three men and
a boy yet, till my mother be dead: but what though?
yet I live like a poor gentleman born.

sp.speaker: Anne
sp.ab: I may not go in without your worship: they will not
sit till you come.

sp.speaker: Slender
sp.ab: I' faith, I'll eat nothing; I thank you as much as
though I did.

sp.speaker: Anne
sp.ab: I pray you, sir, walk in.

sp.speaker: Slender
sp.ab: I had rather walk here, I thank you. I bruised
my shin th' other day with playing at sword and
dagger with a master of fence; three veneys for
a dish of stewed prunes; and, by my troth, I
cannot abide the smell of hot meat since. Why do your
dogs bark so? be there bears i' the town?

sp.speaker: Anne
sp.ab: I think there are, sir; I heard them talked of.

sp.speaker: Slender
sp.ab: I love the sport well; but I shall as soon quarrel
at it as any man in England. You are afraid, if you
see the bear loose, are you not?

sp.speaker: Anne
sp.ab: Ay, indeed, sir.

sp.speaker: Slender
sp.ab: That's meat and drink to me, now. I have seen
Sackerson loose twenty times, and have taken him
by the chain; but, I warrant you, the women have
so cried and shrieked at it, that it passed; but
women, indeed, cannot abide 'em; they are very
ill-favoured rough things.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.ab: Come, gentle Master Slender, come; we stay for you.

sp.speaker: Slender
sp.ab: I'll eat nothing, I thank you, sir.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.ab: By cock and pie, you shall not choose, sir! come,
come.

sp.speaker: Slender
sp.ab: Nay, pray you, lead the way.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.ab: Come on, sir.

sp.speaker: Slender
sp.ab: Mistress Anne, yourself shall go first.

sp.speaker: Anne
sp.ab: Not I, sir: pray you, keep on.

sp.speaker: Slender
sp.ab: Truly, I will not go first; truly, la! I will not do
you that wrong.

sp.speaker: Anne
sp.ab: I pray you, sir.

sp.speaker: Slender
sp.ab: I'll rather be unmannerly than troublesome. You do
yourself wrong, indeed, la!

div.head: Act 1, Scene 2
div.stage: Enter SIR HUGH EVANS and SIMPLE.

sp.speaker: Evans
sp.ab: Go your ways, and ask of Doctor Caius' house
which is the way: and there dwells one Mistress
Quickly, which is in the manner of his nurse, or
his dry nurse, or his cook, or his laundry, his
washer, and his wringer.

sp.speaker: Simple
sp.ab: Well, sir.

sp.speaker: Evans
sp.ab: Nay it is petter yet. Give her this letter; for
it is a 'oman that altogether's acquaintance with
Mistress Anne Page: and the letter is, to desire
and require her to solicit your master's desires
to Mistress Anne Page. I pray you, be gone: I
will make an end of my dinner; there's pippins and
cheese to come.

div.head: Act 1, Scene 3
div.stage: A room in the Garter Inn.
Enter FALSTAFF, HOST, BARDOLPH, NYM, PISTOL, and ROBIN.

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: Mine host of the Garter!

sp.speaker: Host
sp.ab: What says my bully-rook? speak scholarly and wisely.

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: Truly, mine host, I must turn away some of my
followers.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.ab: Discard, bully Hercules; cashier: let them wag; trot,
trot.

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: I sit at ten pounds a week.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.ab: Thou'rt an emperor, Caesar, Keisar, and Pheezar.
I will entertain Bardolph; he shall draw, he shall
tap: said I well, bully Hector?

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: Do so, good mine host.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.ab: I have spoke; let him follow.
Let me see thee froth and lime: I am at a word;
follow.

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: Bardolph, follow him. A tapster is a good trade:
an old cloak makes a new jerkin; a withered servingman
a fresh tapster. Go; adieu.

sp.speaker: Bardolph
sp.ab: It is a life that I have desired: I will thrive.

sp.speaker: Pistol
sp.ab: O base Hungarian wight! wilt thou the spigot wield?

sp.speaker: Nym
sp.ab: He was gotten in drink: is not the humour conceited?

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: I am glad I am so acquit of this tinderbox: his
thefts were too open; his filching was like an
unskilful singer; he kept not time.

sp.speaker: Nym
sp.ab: The good humour is to steal at a minute's rest.

sp.speaker: Pistol
sp.ab: “Convey,” the wise it call. “Steal!” foh! a fico for
the phrase!

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: Well, sirs, I am almost out at heels.

sp.speaker: Pistol
sp.l: Why, then, let kibes ensue.

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: There is no remedy; I must conycatch; I must shift.

sp.speaker: Pistol
sp.l: Young ravens must have food.

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: Which of you know Ford of this town?

sp.speaker: Pistol
sp.l: I ken the wight: he is of substance good.

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: My honest lads, I will tell you what I am about.

sp.speaker: Pistol
sp.l: Two yards, and more.

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: No quips now, Pistol! Indeed, I am in the waist
two yards about: but I am now about no waste; I
am about thrift. Briefly, I do mean to make love
to Ford's wife: I spy entertainment in her; she
discourses, she carves, she gives the leer of
invitation: I can construe the action of her
familiar style; and the hardest voice of her
behaviour, to be Englished rightly, is, “I am Sir John
Falstaff's.”

sp.speaker: Pistol
sp.ab: He hath studied her well, and translated her will, out
of honesty into English.

sp.speaker: Nym
sp.ab: The anchor is deep: will that humour pass?

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: Now, the report goes she has all the rule of her
husband's purse: he hath a legend of angels.

sp.speaker: Pistol
sp.ab: As many devils entertain; and “To her, boy,” say I.

sp.speaker: Nym
sp.ab: The humour rises; it is good: humour me the angels.

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: I have writ me here a letter to her: and here
another to Page's wife, who even now gave me good
eyes too, examined my parts with most judicious
oeillades; sometimes the beam of her view gilded my
foot, sometimes my portly belly.

sp.speaker: Pistol
sp.l: Then did the sun on dunghill shine.

sp.speaker: Nym
sp.ab: I thank thee for that humour.

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: O, she did so course o'er my exteriors with such
a greedy intention, that the appetite of her eye
did seem to scorch me up like a burning-glass!
Here's another letter to her: she bears the purse
too; she is a region in Guiana, all gold and
bounty. I will be cheaters to them both, and they
shall be exchequers to me; they shall be my East
and West Indies, and I will trade to them both.
Go bear thou this letter to Mistress Page; and
thou this to Mistress Ford: we will thrive, lads, we
will thrive.

sp.speaker: Pistol
sp.l: Shall I Sir Pandarus of Troy become,
And by my side wear steel? then, Lucifer take all!

sp.speaker: Nym
sp.ab: I will run no base humour: here, take the
humour-letter: I will keep the haviour of reputation.

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.l: Hold, sirrah, bear you these letters tightly;
Sail like my pinnace to these golden shores.
Rogues, hence, avaunt! vanish like hailstones go:
Trudge, plod away i' the hoof; seek shelter, pack!
Falstaff will learn the humour of the age,
French thrift, you rogues; myself and skirted page. Exeunt Falstaff and Robin.

sp.speaker: Pistol
sp.l: Let vultures gripe thy guts! for gourd and fullam holds,
And high and low beguiles the rich and poor:
Tester I'll have in pouch when thou shalt lack,
Base Phrygian Turk!

sp.speaker: Nym
sp.ab: I have operations in my head which be humours of
revenge.

sp.speaker: Pistol
sp.l: Wilt thou revenge?

sp.speaker: Nym
sp.l: By welkin and her star!

sp.speaker: Pistol
sp.l: With wit or steel?

sp.speaker: Nym
sp.l: With both the humours, I:
I will discuss the humour of this love to Page.

sp.speaker: Pistol
sp.l: And I to Ford shall eke unfold
How Falstaff varlet vile,
His dove will prove, his gold will hold,
And his soft couch defile.

sp.speaker: Nym
sp.ab: My humour shall not cool: I will incense Page to
deal with poison; I will possess him with
yellowness, for the revolt of mine is dangerous: that
is my true humour.

sp.speaker: Pistol
sp.ab: Thou art the Mars of malcontents: I second thee; troop
on.

div.head: Act 1, Scene 4
div.stage: A room in DOCTOR CAIUS'S house.
Enter MISTRESS QUICKLY, SIMPLE, and RUGBY.

sp.speaker: Quickly
sp.ab: What, John Rugby! I pray thee, go to the casement,
and see if you can see my master, Master Doctor
Caius, coming. If he do, i' faith, and find any
body in the house, here will be an old abusing of
God's patience and the king's English.

sp.speaker: Rugby
sp.ab: I'll go watch.

sp.speaker: Quickly
sp.ab: Go; and we'll have a posset for't soon at night,
in faith, at the latter end of a seacoal fire.
An honest, willing, kind fellow, as ever servant
shall come in house withal, and, I warrant you,
no tell-tale nor no breed-bate: his worst fault
is, that he is given to prayer; he is something
peevish that way: but nobody but has his fault;
but let that pass. Peter Simple, you say your name is?

sp.speaker: Simple
sp.ab: Ay, for fault of a better.

sp.speaker: Quickly
sp.ab: And Master Slender's your master?

sp.speaker: Simple
sp.ab: Ay, forsooth.

sp.speaker: Quickly
sp.ab: Does he not wear a great round beard, like a glover's
paring-knife?

sp.speaker: Simple
sp.ab: No, forsooth: he hath but a little whey-face with a
little yellow beard, a Cain-coloured beard.

sp.speaker: Quickly
sp.ab: A softly-sprighted man, is he not?

sp.speaker: Simple
sp.ab: Ay, forsooth: but he is as tall a man of his
hands as any is between this and his head; he hath
fought with a warrener.

sp.speaker: Quickly
sp.ab: How say you? O, I should remember him: does he
not hold up his head, as it were, and strut in his
gait?

sp.speaker: Simple
sp.ab: Yes, indeed, does he.

sp.speaker: Quickly
sp.ab: Well, heaven send Anne Page no worse fortune!
Tell Master Parson Evans I will do what I can for your
master: Anne is a good girl, and I wish —

sp.speaker: Rugby
sp.ab: Out, alas! here comes my master.

sp.speaker: Quickly
sp.ab: We shall all be shent. Run in here, good young
man; go into this closet: he will not stay long.
What, John Rugby! John! what, John, I say! Go,
John, go inquire for my master; I doubt he be not
well, that he comes not home.
sp.l: And down, down, adown-a, etc. Enter DOCTOR CAIUS.

sp.speaker: Caius
sp.ab: Vat is you sing? I do not like des toys. Pray
you, go and vetch me in my closet un boîtier
vert, a box, a green-a box: do intend vat I speak? a
green-a box.

sp.speaker: Quickly
sp.ab: Ay, forsooth; I'll fetch it you.
I am glad he went not in himself: if he had found the
young man, he would have been horn-mad.

sp.speaker: Caius
sp.ab: Fe, fe, fe, fe! ma foi, il fait fort chaud. Je m'en
vais à la cour — la grande affaire.

sp.speaker: Quickly
sp.ab: Is it this, sir?

sp.speaker: Caius
sp.ab: Oui; mette le au mon pocket: dépêche, quickly. Vere is
dat knave Rugby?

sp.speaker: Quickly
sp.ab: What, John Rugby! John!

sp.speaker: Rugby
sp.ab: Here, sir!

sp.speaker: Caius
sp.ab: You are John Rugby, and you are Jack Rugby. Come,
take-a your rapier, and come after my heel to the
court.

sp.speaker: Rugby
sp.ab: 'Tis ready, sir, here in the porch.

sp.speaker: Caius
sp.ab: By my trot, I tarry too long. 'Od's me! Qu'ai-j'
oublié! dere is some simples in my closet, dat
I vill not for the varld I shall leave behind.

sp.speaker: Quickly
sp.ab: Ay me, he'll find the young man there, and be mad!

sp.speaker: Caius
sp.ab: O diable, diable! vat is in my closet? Villainy!
Larron!
Rugby, my rapier!

sp.speaker: Quickly
sp.ab: Good master, be content.

sp.speaker: Caius
sp.ab: Wherefore shall I be content-a?

sp.speaker: Quickly
sp.ab: The young man is an honest man.

sp.speaker: Caius
sp.ab: What shall de honest man do in my closet? dere is no
honest man dat shall come in my closet.

sp.speaker: Quickly
sp.ab: I beseech you, be not so phlegmatic. Hear the
truth of it: he came of an errand to me from Parson
Hugh.

sp.speaker: Caius
sp.ab: Vell.

sp.speaker: Simple
sp.ab: Ay, forsooth; to desire her to —

sp.speaker: Quickly
sp.ab: Peace, I pray you.

sp.speaker: Caius
sp.ab: Peace-a your tongue. Speak-a your tale.

sp.speaker: Simple
sp.ab: To desire this honest gentlewoman, your maid, to
speak a good word to Mistress Anne Page for my master
in the way of marriage.

sp.speaker: Quickly
sp.ab: This is all, indeed, la! but I'll ne'er put my finger
in the fire, and need not.

sp.speaker: Caius
sp.ab: Sir Hugh send-a you? Rugby, baille me some paper.
Tarry you a little-a while.

sp.speaker: Quickly
sp.ab: I am glad he is so quiet: if he had been throughly
moved, you should have heard him so loud and so
melancholy. But notwithstanding, man, I'll do
you your master what good I can: and the very
yea and the no is, the French doctor, my master, — I
may call him my master, look you, for I keep his
house; and I wash, wring, brew, bake, scour,
dress meat and drink, make the beds, and do all
myself, —

sp.speaker: Simple
sp.ab: 'Tis a great charge to come under one body's hand.

sp.speaker: Quickly
sp.ab: Are you avised o' that? you shall find it a great
charge: and to be up early and down late; but
notwithstanding, — to tell you in your ear; I
would have no words of it, — my master himself is
in love with Mistress Anne Page: but notwithstanding
that, I know Anne's mind, — that's neither here nor
there.

sp.speaker: Caius
sp.ab: You jack'nape, give-a this letter to Sir Hugh;
by gar, it is a shallenge: I will cut his troat
in de park; and I will teach a scurvy jack-a-nape
priest to meddle or make. You may be gone; it is
not good you tarry here. By gar, I will cut all
his two stones; by gar, he shall not have a stone to
throw at his dog.

sp.speaker: Quickly
sp.ab: Alas, he speaks but for his friend.

sp.speaker: Caius
sp.ab: It is no matter-a ver dat: do not you tell-a me
dat I shall have Anne Page for myself? By gar,
I vill kill de Jack priest; and I have appointed
mine host of de Jarteer to measure our weapon. By gar,
I will myself have Anne Page.

sp.speaker: Quickly
sp.ab: Sir, the maid loves you, and all shall be well.
We must give folks leave to prate: what, the good-jer!

sp.speaker: Caius
sp.ab: Rugby, come to the court with me. By gar, if I
have not Anne Page, I shall turn your head out of my
door. Follow my heels, Rugby.

sp.speaker: Quickly
sp.ab: You shall have An fool's-head of your own. No,
I know Anne's mind for that: never a woman in
Windsor knows more of Anne's mind than I do: nor can
do more than I do with her, I thank heaven.

sp.speaker: Fenton
sp.ab: Who's within there? ho!

sp.speaker: Quickly
sp.ab: Who's there, I trow! Come near the house, I pray you.

sp.speaker: Fenton
sp.ab: How now, good woman! how dost thou?

sp.speaker: Quickly
sp.ab: The better that it pleases your good worship to ask.

sp.speaker: Fenton
sp.ab: What news? how does pretty Mistress Anne?

sp.speaker: Quickly
sp.ab: In truth, sir, and she is pretty, and honest,
and gentle; and one that is your friend, I can tell
you that by the way; I praise heaven for it.

sp.speaker: Fenton
sp.ab: Shall I do any good, thinkest thou? shall I not lose
my suit?

sp.speaker: Quickly
sp.ab: Troth, sir, all is in his hands above: but
notwithstanding, Master Fenton, I'll be sworn on
a book, she loves you. Have not your worship a wart
above your eye?

sp.speaker: Fenton
sp.ab: Yes, marry, have I; what of that?

sp.speaker: Quickly
sp.ab: Well, thereby hangs a tale: good faith, it is
such another Nan; but, I detest, an honest maid
as ever broke bread: we had an hour's talk of
that wart. I shall never laugh but in that maid's
company! But indeed she is given too much to allicholy
and musing: but for you — well, go to.

sp.speaker: Fenton
sp.ab: Well, I shall see her to-day. Hold, there's money
for thee; let me have thy voice in my behalf: if thou
seest her before me, commend me.

sp.speaker: Quickly
sp.ab: Will I? i' faith, that we will; and I will tell
your worship more of the wart the next time we have
confidence; and of other wooers.

sp.speaker: Fenton
sp.ab: Well, farewell; I am in great haste now.

sp.speaker: Quickly
sp.ab: Farewell to your worship.
Truly, an honest gentleman: but Anne loves him
not; for I know Anne's mind as well as another does.
Out upon't! what have I forgot?

div.head: Act 2, Scene 1
div.stage: Enter MISTRESS PAGE, with a letter.

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.ab: What, have I scaped love-letters in the holiday-time
of my beauty, and am I now a subject for them? Let me
see.
“Ask me no reason why I love you; for though Love
use Reason for his precisian, he admits him not
for his counsellor. You are not young, no more
am I; go to then, there's sympathy: you are merry,
so am I; ha, ha! then there's more sympathy: you
love sack, and so do I; would you desire better
sympathy? Let it suffice thee, Mistress Page, — at
the least, if the love of soldier can suffice, —
that I love thee. I will not say, pity me; 'tis
not a soldier-like phrase: but I say, love me. By me,
JOHN FALSTAFF.”
What a Herod of Jewry is this! O wicked, wicked
world! One that is well-nigh worn to pieces with
age to show himself a young gallant! What an
unweighed behaviour hath this Flemish drunkard
picked — with the devil's name! — out of my conversation,
that he dares in this manner assay me? Why, he
hath not been thrice in my company! What should
I say to him? I was then frugal of my mirth:
Heaven forgive me! Why, I'll exhibit a bill in
the parliament for the putting down of men. How
shall I be revenged on him? for revenged I will be, as
sure as his guts are made of puddings.

sp.speaker: Mistress Ford
sp.ab: Mistress Page! trust me, I was going to your house.

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.ab: And, trust me, I was coming to you. You look very ill.

sp.speaker: Mistress Ford
sp.ab: Nay, I'll ne'er believe that; I have to show to the
contrary.

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.ab: Faith, but you do, in my mind.

sp.speaker: Mistress Ford
sp.ab: Well, I do then; yet I say I could show you to
the contrary. O Mistress Page, give me some counsel!

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.ab: What's the matter, woman?

sp.speaker: Mistress Ford
sp.ab: O woman, if it were not for one trifling respect, I
could come to such honour!

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.ab: Hang the trifle, woman! take the honour. What is it?
dispense with trifles; what is it?

sp.speaker: Mistress Ford
sp.ab: If I would but go to hell for an eternal moment or so,
I could be knighted.

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.ab: What? thou liest! Sir Alice Ford! These knights
will hack; and so thou shouldst not alter the article
of thy gentry.

sp.speaker: Mistress Ford
sp.ab: We burn daylight; here, read, read; perceive how
I might be knighted. I shall think the worse of
fat men, as long as I have an eye to make difference
of men's liking; and yet he would not swear;
praised women's modesty; and gave such orderly
and well-behaved reproof to all uncomeliness,
that I would have sworn his disposition would
have gone to the truth of his words; but they do
no more adhere and keep place together than the
hundred Psalms to the tune of “Greensleeves.”
What tempest, I trow, threw this whale, with so
many tuns of oil in his belly, ashore at Windsor?
How shall I be revenged on him? I think the best
way were to entertain him with hope, till the
wicked fire of lust have melted him in his own grease.
Did you ever hear the like?

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.ab: Letter for letter, but that the name of Page and
Ford differs! To thy great comfort in this mystery
of ill opinions, here's the twin-brother of thy
letter: but let thine inherit first; for, I
protest, mine never shall. I warrant he hath a
thousand of these letters, writ with blank space
for different names, — sure, more, — and these are
of the second edition: he will print them, out
of doubt; for he cares not what he puts into the
press, when he would put us two. I had rather be
a giantess, and lie under Mount Pelion. Well, I
will find you twenty lascivious turtles ere one chaste
man.

sp.speaker: Mistress Ford
sp.ab: Why, this is the very same; the very hand, the very
words. What doth he think of us?

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.ab: Nay, I know not: it makes me almost ready to
wrangle with mine own honesty. I'll entertain
myself like one that I am not acquainted withal;
for, sure, unless he know some strain in me, that
I know not myself, he would never have boarded me in
this fury.

sp.speaker: Mistress Ford
sp.ab: “Boarding,” call you it? I'll be sure to keep him
above deck.

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.ab: So will I: if he come under my hatches, I'll
never to sea again. Let's be revenged on him:
let's appoint him a meeting; give him a show of
comfort in his suit and lead him on with a
fine-baited delay, till he hath pawned his horses to
mine host of the Garter.

sp.speaker: Mistress Ford
sp.ab: Nay, I will consent to act any villainy against
him, that may not sully the chariness of our
honesty. O, that my husband saw this letter! it would
give eternal food to his jealousy.

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.ab: Why, look where he comes; and my good man too:
he's as far from jealousy as I am from giving
him cause; and that I hope is an unmeasurable
distance.

sp.speaker: Mistress Ford
sp.ab: You are the happier woman.

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.ab: Let's consult together against this greasy knight.
Come hither.
sp.stage: Enter FORD with PISTOL, and PAGE with NYM.

sp.speaker: Ford
sp.ab: Well, I hope it be not so.

sp.speaker: Pistol
sp.l: Hope is a curtal dog in some affairs:
Sir John affects thy wife.

sp.speaker: Ford
sp.ab: Why, sir, my wife is not young.

sp.speaker: Pistol
sp.l: He woos both high and low, both rich and poor.
Both young and old, one with another, Ford;
He loves the gallimaufry: Ford, perpend.

sp.speaker: Ford
sp.ab: Love my wife!

sp.speaker: Pistol
sp.l: With liver burning hot. Prevent, or go thou,
Like Sir Actaeon he, with Ringwood at thy heels:
O, odious is the name!

sp.speaker: Ford
sp.ab: What name, sir?

sp.speaker: Pistol
sp.l: The horn, I say. Farewell.
Take heed, have open eye, for thieves do foot by night:
Take heed, ere summer comes or cuckoo-birds do sing.
Away, Sir Corporal Nym!
Believe it, Page; he speaks sense. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ford
sp.ab: I will be patient; I will find out this.

sp.speaker: Nym
sp.ab: And this is true; I like not the humour of lying.
He hath wronged me in some humours: I should have
borne the humoured letter to her; but I have a
sword and it shall bite upon my necessity. He
loves your wife; there's the short and the long.
My name is Corporal Nym; I speak and I avouch;
'tis true: my name is Nym and Falstaff loves your
wife. Adieu. I love not the humour of bread and
cheese, and there's the humour of it. Adieu.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.ab: “The humour of it,” quoth 'a! here's a fellow frights
English out of his wits.

sp.speaker: Ford
sp.ab: I will seek out Falstaff.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.ab: I never heard such a drawling, affecting rogue.

sp.speaker: Ford
sp.ab: If I do find it; well.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.ab: I will not believe such a Cataian, though the priest
o' the town commended him for a true man.

sp.speaker: Ford
sp.ab: 'Twas a good sensible fellow: well.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.ab: How now, Meg!
sp.stage: Mrs. Page and Mrs. Ford come forward.

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.ab: Whither go you, George? Hark you.

sp.speaker: Mistress Ford
sp.ab: How now, sweet Frank! why art thou melancholy?

sp.speaker: Ford
sp.ab: I melancholy! I am not melancholy. Get you home, go.

sp.speaker: Mistress Ford
sp.ab: Faith, thou hast some crotchets in thy head. Now, will
you go, Mistress Page?

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.ab: Have with you, You'll come to dinner, George.
Look who comes yonder; she shall be our messenger to
this paltry knight.

sp.speaker: Mistress Ford
sp.ab: Trust me, I thought on her: she'll fit it.

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.ab: You are come to see my daughter Anne?

sp.speaker: Quickly
sp.ab: Ay, forsooth; and, I pray, how does good Mistress
Anne?

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.ab: Go in with us and see: we have an hour's talk with
you.
sp.stage: Exeunt Mrs. Page, Mrs. Ford, and Mrs. Quickly.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.ab: How now, Master Ford!

sp.speaker: Ford
sp.ab: You heard what this knave told me, did you not?

sp.speaker: Page
sp.ab: Yes: and you heard what the other told me?

sp.speaker: Ford
sp.ab: Do you think there is truth in them?

sp.speaker: Page
sp.ab: Hang 'em, slaves! I do not think the knight would
offer it: but these that accuse him in his intent
towards our wives are a yoke of his discarded men;
very rogues, now they be out of service.

sp.speaker: Ford
sp.ab: Were they his men?

sp.speaker: Page
sp.ab: Marry, were they.

sp.speaker: Ford
sp.ab: I like it never the better for that. Does he lie at
the Garter?

sp.speaker: Page
sp.ab: Ay, marry, does he. If he should intend this
voyage towards my wife, I would turn her loose
to him; and what he gets more of her than sharp words,
let it lie on my head.

sp.speaker: Ford
sp.ab: I do not misdoubt my wife; but I would be loath
to turn them together. A man may be too confident:
I would have nothing lie on my head: I cannot be thus
satisfied.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.ab: Look where my ranting host of the Garter comes:
there is either liquor in his pate or money in
his purse when he looks so merrily.
How now, mine host!

sp.speaker: Host
sp.ab: How now, bully-rook! thou'rt a gentleman. Cavaleiro
Justice, I say!

sp.speaker: Shallow
sp.ab: I follow, mine host, I follow. Good even and
twenty, good Master Page! Master Page, will you go
with us? we have sport in hand.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.ab: Tell him, cavaleiro justice; tell him, bully-rook.

sp.speaker: Shallow
sp.ab: Sir, there is a fray to be fought between Sir Hugh the
Welsh priest and Caius the French doctor.

sp.speaker: Ford
sp.ab: Good mine host o' the Garter, a word with you.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.ab: What sayest thou, my bully-rook?

sp.speaker: Shallow
sp.ab: Will you go with us to behold it? My merry host
hath had the measuring of their weapons; and, I
think, hath appointed them contrary places; for,
believe me, I hear the parson is no jester. Hark, I
will tell you what our sport shall be.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.ab: Hast thou no suit against my knight, my
guest-cavalier?

sp.speaker: Ford
sp.ab: None, I protest: but I'll give you a pottle of
burnt sack to give me recourse to him and tell him my
name is Brook; only for a jest.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.ab: My hand, bully; thou shalt have egress and
regress; — said I well? — and thy name shall be Brook. It
is a merry knight. Will you go, An-heires?

sp.speaker: Shallow
sp.ab: Have with you, mine host.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.ab: I have heard the Frenchman hath good skill in his
rapier.

sp.speaker: Shallow
sp.ab: Tut, sir, I could have told you more. In these
times you stand on distance, your passes,
stoccadoes. and I know not what: 'tis the heart,
Master Page; 'tis here, 'tis here. I have seen
the time, with my long sword I would have made you
four tall fellows skip like rats.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.ab: Here, boys, here, here shall we wag?

sp.speaker: Page
sp.ab: Have with you. I had rather hear them scold than
fight.

sp.speaker: Ford
sp.ab: Though Page be a secure fool, and stands so firmly
on his wife's frailty, yet I cannot put off my
opinion so easily: she was in his company at
Page's house; and what they made there, I know
not. Well, I will look further into't; and I have
a disguise to sound Falstaff. If I find her
honest, I lose not my labour; if she be otherwise,
'tis labour well bestowed.

div.head: Act 2, Scene 2
div.stage: A room in the Garter Inn.

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: I will not lend thee a penny.

sp.speaker: Pistol
sp.ab: Why, then the world's mine oyster, Which I with sword
will open.

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: Not a penny. I have been content, sir, you should
lay my countenance to pawn: I have grated upon
my good friends for three reprieves for you and
your coach-fellow Nym; or else you had looked
through the grate, like a geminy of baboons. I
am damned in hell for swearing to gentlemen my
friends, you were good soldiers and tall fellows;
and when Mistress Bridget lost the handle of her fan,
I took't upon mine honour thou hadst it not.

sp.speaker: Pistol
sp.l: Didst not thou share? hadst thou not fifteen pence?

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: Reason, you rogue, reason: thinkest thou I'll
endanger my soul gratis? At a word, hang no more
about me, I am no gibbet for you. Go. A short
knife and a throng! To your manor of Pickthatch!
Go. You'll not bear a letter for me, you rogue!
you stand upon your honour! Why, thou unconfinable
baseness, it is as much as I can do to keep the
terms of my honour precise: I, I, I myself
sometimes, leaving the fear of God on the left
hand and hiding mine honour in my necessity, am
fain to shuffle, to hedge and to lurch; and yet
you, rogue, will ensconce your rags, your
cat-a-mountain looks, your red-lattice phrases,
and your bold-beating oaths, under the shelter of your
honour! You will not do it, you!

sp.speaker: Pistol
sp.l: I do relent: what would thou more of man? Enter ROBIN.

sp.speaker: Robin
sp.ab: Sir, here's a woman would speak with you.

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: Let her approach.

sp.speaker: Quickly
sp.ab: Give your worship good morrow.

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: Good morrow, goodwife.

sp.speaker: Quickly
sp.ab: Not so, an't please your worship.

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: Good maid, then.

sp.speaker: Quickly
sp.ab: I'll be sworn, As my mother was, the first hour I was
born.

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: I do believe the swearer. What with me?

sp.speaker: Quickly
sp.ab: Shall I vouchsafe your worship a word or two?

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: Two thousand, fair woman: and I'll vouchsafe thee the
hearing.

sp.speaker: Quickly
sp.ab: There is one Mistress Ford, sir: — I pray come a
little nearer this ways: — I myself dwell with Master
Doctor Caius, —

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: Well, on: Mistress Ford, you say, —

sp.speaker: Quickly
sp.ab: Your worship says very true: I pray your worship, come
a little nearer this ways.

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: I warrant thee, nobody hears; mine own people, mine
own people.

sp.speaker: Quickly
sp.ab: Are they so? God bless them and make them his
servants!

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: Well, Mistress Ford; what of her?

sp.speaker: Quickly
sp.ab: Why, sir, she's a good creature. Lord, Lord! your
worship's a wanton! Well, heaven forgive you and all
of us, I pray!

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: Mistress Ford; come, Mistress Ford, —

sp.speaker: Quickly
sp.ab: Marry, this is the short and the long of it; you
have brought her into such a canaries as 'tis
wonderful. The best courtier of them all, when
the court lay at Windsor, could never have brought
her to such a canary. Yet there has been knights,
and lords, and gentlemen, with their coaches, I
warrant you, coach after coach, letter after
letter, gift after gift; smelling so sweetly,
all musk, and so rushling, I warrant you, in silk
and gold; and in such alligant terms; and in such
wine and sugar of the best and the fairest, that
would have won any woman's heart; and I warrant
you, they could never get an eye-wink of her: I
had myself twenty angels given me this morning;
but I defy all angels, in any such sort, as they
say, but in the way of honesty: and, I warrant
you, they could never get her so much as sip on
a cup with the proudest of them all: and yet
there has been earls, nay, which is more, pensioners;
but, I warrant you, all is one with her.

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: But what says she to me? be brief, my good
she-Mercury.

sp.speaker: Quickly
sp.ab: Marry, she hath received your letter, for the
which she thanks you a thousand times; and she
gives you to notify that her husband will be absence
from his house between ten and eleven.

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: Ten and eleven?

sp.speaker: Quickly
sp.ab: Ay, forsooth; and then you may come and see the
picture, she says, that you wot of: Master Ford,
her husband, will be from home. Alas! the sweet
woman leads an ill life with him: he's a very
jealousy man: she leads a very frampold life with him,
good heart.

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: Ten and eleven. Woman, commend me to her; I will not
fail her.

sp.speaker: Quickly
sp.ab: Why, you say well. But I have another messenger
to your worship. Mistress Page hath her hearty
commendations to you too: and let me tell you in
your ear, she's as fartuous a civil modest wife,
and one, I tell you, that will not miss you
morning nor evening prayer, as any is in Windsor,
whoe'er be the other: and she bade me tell your
worship that her husband is seldom from home;
but she hopes there will come a time. I never
knew a woman so dote upon a man: surely I think you
have charms, la; yes, in truth.

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: Not I, I assure thee: setting the attraction of my
good parts aside I have no other charms.

sp.speaker: Quickly
sp.ab: Blessing on your heart for't!

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: But, I pray thee, tell me this: has Ford's wife
and Page's wife acquainted each other how they love
me?

sp.speaker: Quickly
sp.ab: That were a jest indeed! they have not so little
grace, I hope: that were a trick indeed! but
Mistress Page would desire you to send her your
little page, of all loves: her husband has a
marvellous infection to the little page; and
truly Master Page is an honest man. Never a wife
in Windsor leads a better life than she does: do
what she will, say what she will, take all, pay
all, go to bed when she list, rise when she list,
all is as she will: and truly she deserves it;
for if there be a kind woman in Windsor, she is one.
You must send her your page; no remedy.

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: Why, I will.

sp.speaker: Quickly
sp.ab: Nay, but do so, then: and, look you, he may come
and go between you both; and in any case have a
nay-word, that you may know one another's mind,
and the boy never need to understand any thing;
for 'tis not good that children should know any
wickedness: old folks, you know, have discretion, as
they say, and know the world.

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: Fare thee well: commend me to them both: there's
my purse; I am yet thy debtor Boy, go along with this
woman.
This news distracts me!

sp.speaker: Pistol
sp.l: This punk is one of Cupid's carriers:
“Clap on more sails; pursue; up with your fights:
Give fire: she is my prize, or ocean whelm them all! Exit.

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: Sayest thou so, old Jack? go thy ways; I'll make
more of thy old body than I have done. Will they
yet look after thee? Wilt thou, after the expense
of so much money, be now a gainer? Good body, I
thank thee. Let them say 'tis grossly done; so it be
fairly done, no matter.

sp.speaker: Bardolph
sp.ab: Sir John, there's one Master Brook below would
fain speak with you, and be acquainted with you;
and hath sent your worship a morning's draught of
sack.

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: Brook is his name?

sp.speaker: Bardolph
sp.ab: Ay, sir.

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: Call him in.
Such Brooks are welcome to me, that o'erflows
such liquor. Ah, ha! Mistress Ford and Mistress Page,
have I encompassed you? go to; via!

sp.speaker: Ford
sp.ab: Bless you, sir!

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: And you, sir! Would you speak with me?

sp.speaker: Ford
sp.ab: I make bold to press with so little preparation upon
you.

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: You're welcome. What's your will? Give us leave,
drawer.

sp.speaker: Ford
sp.ab: Sir, I am a gentleman that have spent much: my name is
Brook.

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: Good Master Brook, I desire more acquaintance of you.

sp.speaker: Ford
sp.ab: Good Sir John, I sue for yours: not to charge
you; for I must let you understand I think myself
in better plight for a lender than you are: the
which hath something emboldened me to this
unseasoned intrusion; for they say, if money go
before, all ways do lie open.

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: Money is a good soldier, sir, and will on.

sp.speaker: Ford
sp.ab: Troth, and I have a bag of money here troubles
me: if you will help to bear it, Sir John, take all,
or half, for easing me of the carriage.

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: Sir, I know not how I may deserve to be your porter.

sp.speaker: Ford
sp.ab: I will tell you, sir, if you will give me the hearing.

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: Speak, good Master Brook: I shall be glad to be your
servant.

sp.speaker: Ford
sp.ab: Sir, I hear you are a scholar, — I will be brief
with you, — and you have been a man long known to
me, though I had never so good means, as desire,
to make myself acquainted with you. I shall
discover a thing to you, wherein I must very much
lay open mine own imperfection: but good Sir
John, as you have one eye upon my follies, as
you hear them unfolded, turn another into the
register of your own; that I may pass with a
reproof the easier, sith you yourself know how easy it
is to be such an offender.

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: Very well, sir; proceed.

sp.speaker: Ford
sp.ab: There is a gentlewoman in this town; her husband's
name is Ford.

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: Well, sir.

sp.speaker: Ford
sp.ab: I have long loved her, and, I protest to you,
bestowed much on her; followed her with a doting
observance; engrossed opportunities to meet her;
fee'd every slight occasion that could but
niggardly give me sight of her; not only bought
many presents to give her, but have given largely
to many to know what she would have given; briefly,
I have pursued her as love hath pursued me; which
hath been on the wing of all occasions. But
whatsoever I have merited, either in my mind or
in my means, meed, I am sure, I have received
none; unless experience be a jewel that I have
purchased at an infinite rate, and that hath taught me
to say this:

lg.l: “Love like a shadow flies when substance love pursues;
Pursuing that that flies, and flying what pursues.

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: Have you received no promise of satisfaction at her
hands?

sp.speaker: Ford
sp.ab: Never.

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: Have you importuned her to such a purpose?

sp.speaker: Ford
sp.ab: Never.

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: Of what quality was your love, then?

sp.speaker: Ford
sp.ab: Like a fair house built on another man's ground;
so that I have lost my edifice by mistaking the place
where I erected it.

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: To what purpose have you unfolded this to me?

sp.speaker: Ford
sp.ab: When I have told you that, I have told you all.
Some say, that though she appear honest to me,
yet in other places she enlargeth her mirth so
far that there is shrewd construction made of
her. Now, Sir John, here is the heart of my
purpose: you are a gentleman of excellent breeding,
admirable discourse, of great admittance, authentic
in your place and person, generally allowed for
your many warlike, court-like, and learned
preparations.

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: O, sir!

sp.speaker: Ford
sp.ab: Believe it, for you know it. There is money;
spend it, spend it; spend more; spend all I have;
only give me so much of your time in exchange of
it, as to lay an amiable siege to the honesty of
this Ford's wife: use your art of wooing; win
her to consent to you: if any man may, you may as soon
as any.

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: Would it apply well to the vehemency of your
affection, that I should win what you would enjoy?
Methinks you prescribe to yourself very
preposterously.

sp.speaker: Ford
sp.ab: O, understand my drift. She dwells so securely
on the excellency of her honour, that the folly
of my soul dares not present itself: she is too
bright to be looked against. Now, could I come
to her with any detection in my hand, my desires
had instance and argument to commend themselves:
I could drive her then from the ward of her
purity, her reputation, her marriage vow, and a
thousand other her defences, which now are too
too strongly embattled against me. What say you to't,
Sir John?

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: Master Brook, I will first make bold with your
money; next, give me your hand; and last, as I
am a gentleman, you shall, if you will, enjoy Ford's
wife.

sp.speaker: Ford
sp.ab: O good sir!

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: I say you shall.

sp.speaker: Ford
sp.ab: Want no money, Sir John; you shall want none.

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: Want no Mistress Ford, Master Brook: you shall
want none. I shall be with her, I may tell you,
by her own appointment; even as you came in to
me, her assistant or go-between parted from me:
I say I shall be with her between ten and eleven;
for at that time the jealous rascally knave her
husband will be forth. Come you to me at night; you
shall know how I speed.

sp.speaker: Ford
sp.ab: I am blest in your acquaintance. Do you know Ford,
sir?

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: Hang him, poor cuckoldly knave! I know him not:
yet I wrong him to call him poor; they say the
jealous wittolly knave hath masses of money; for
the which his wife seems to me well-favoured. I
will use her as the key of the cuckoldly rogue's
coffer; and there's my harvest-home.

sp.speaker: Ford
sp.ab: I would you knew Ford, sir, that you might avoid him
if you saw him.

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: Hang him, mechanical salt-butter rogue! I will
stare him out of his wits; I will awe him with
my cudgel: it shall hang like a meteor o'er the
cuckold's horns. Master Brook, thou shalt know
I will predominate over the peasant and thou
shalt lie with his wife. Come to me soon at night.
Ford's a knave, and I will aggravate his style;
thou, Master Brook, shalt know him for knave and
cuckold. Come to me soon at night.

sp.speaker: Ford
sp.ab: What a damned Epicurean rascal is this! My heart
is ready to crack with impatience. Who says this
is improvident jealousy? my wife hath sent to
him; the hour is fixed; the match is made. Would
any man have thought this? See the hell of having
a false woman! My bed shall be abused, my coffers
ransacked, my reputation gnawn at; and I shall
not only receive this villainous wrong, but stand
under the adoption of abominable terms, and by
him that does me this wrong. Terms! names! Amaimon
sounds well; Lucifer, well; Barbason, well; yet
they are devils' additions, the names of fiends:
but Cuckold! Wittol! — Cuckold! the devil himself
hath not such a name. Page is an ass, a secure
ass: he will trust his wife: he will not be
jealous. I will rather trust a Fleming with my
butter, Parson Hugh the Welshman with my cheese,
an Irishman with my aqua-vitae bottle, or a thief
to walk my ambling gelding, than my wife with
herself: then she plots, then she ruminates, then
she devises; and what they think in their hearts
they may effect, they will break their hearts
but they will effect. God be praised for my
jealousy! Eleven o' clock the hour. I will prevent
this, detect my wife, be revenged on Falstaff,
and laugh at Page. I will about it; better three
hours too soon than a minute too late. Fie, fie, fie!
cuckold! cuckold! cuckold!

sp.speaker: Caius
sp.ab: Jack Rugby!

sp.speaker: Rugby
sp.ab: Sir?

sp.speaker: Caius
sp.ab: Vat is de clock, Jack?

sp.speaker: Rugby
sp.ab: 'Tis past the hour, sir, that Sir Hugh promised to
meet.

sp.speaker: Caius
sp.ab: By gar, he has save his soul, dat he is no come;
he has pray his Pible well, dat he is no come:
by gar, Jack Rugby, he is dead already, if he be come.

sp.speaker: Rugby
sp.ab: He is wise, sir; he knew your worship would kill him,
if he came.

sp.speaker: Caius
sp.ab: By gar, de herring is no dead so as I vill kill
him. Take your rapier, Jack; I vill tell you how I
vill kill him.

sp.speaker: Rugby
sp.ab: Alas, sir, I cannot fence.

sp.speaker: Caius
sp.ab: villainy, take your rapier.

sp.speaker: Rugby
sp.ab: Forbear; here's company.
sp.stage: Enter HOST, SHALLOW, SLENDER, and PAGE.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.ab: Bless thee, bully-doctor!

sp.speaker: Shallow
sp.ab: Save you, Master Doctor Caius!

sp.speaker: Page
sp.ab: Now, good master doctor!

sp.speaker: Slender
sp.ab: Give you good morrow, sir.

sp.speaker: Caius
sp.ab: Vat be all you, one, two, tree, four, come for?

sp.speaker: Host
sp.ab: To see thee fight, to see thee foin, to see thee
traverse; to see thee here, to see thee there;
to see thee pass thy punto, thy stock, thy reverse,
thy distance, thy montant. Is he dead, my Ethiopian?
is he dead, my Francisco? ha, bully! What says
my AEsculapius? my Galen? my heart of elder? ha! is he
dead, bully-stale? is he dead?

sp.speaker: Caius
sp.ab: By gar, he is de coward Jack priest of de vorld; he is
not show his face.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.ab: Thou art a Castalion-King-Urinal. Hector of Greece, my
boy!

sp.speaker: Caius
sp.ab: I pray you, bear witness that me have stay six
or seven, two, tree hours for him, and he is no come.

sp.speaker: Shallow
sp.ab: He is the wiser man, master doctor: he is a curer
of souls, and you a curer of bodies; if you should
fight, you go against the hair of your professions. Is
it not true, Master Page?

sp.speaker: Page
sp.ab: Master Shallow, you have yourself been a great
fighter, though now a man of peace.

sp.speaker: Shallow
sp.ab: Bodykins, Master Page, though I now be old and
of the peace, if I see a sword out, my finger
itches to make one. Though we are justices and
doctors and churchmen, Master Page, we have some
salt of our youth in us; we are the sons of women,
Master Page.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.ab: 'Tis true, Master Shallow.

sp.speaker: Shallow
sp.ab: It will be found so, Master Page. Master Doctor
Caius, I am come to fetch you home. I am sworn
of the peace: you have showed yourself a wise
physician, and Sir Hugh hath shown himself a wise
and patient churchman. You must go with me, master
doctor.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.ab: Pardon, guest-justice. A word, Mounseur Mockwater.

sp.speaker: Caius
sp.ab: Mockvater! vat is dat?

sp.speaker: Host
sp.ab: Mockwater, in our English tongue, is valour, bully.

sp.speaker: Caius
sp.ab: By gar, then, I have as mush mockvater as de
Englishman. Scurvy jack-dog priest! by gar, me vill
cut his ears.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.ab: He will clapper-claw thee tightly, bully.

sp.speaker: Caius
sp.ab: Clapper-de-claw! vat is dat?

sp.speaker: Host
sp.ab: That is, he will make thee amends.

sp.speaker: Caius
sp.ab: By gar, me do look he shall clapper-de-claw me; for,
by gar, me vill have it.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.ab: And I will provoke him to't, or let him wag.

sp.speaker: Caius
sp.ab: Me tank you for dat.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.ab: And, moreover, bully, — but first, master guest,
and Master Page, and eke Cavaleiro Slender, go you
through the town to Frogmore.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.ab: Sir Hugh is there, is he?

sp.speaker: Host
sp.ab: He is there: see what humour he is in; and I will
bring the doctor about by the fields. Will it do well?

sp.speaker: Shallow
sp.ab: We will do it.

sp.speaker: Page, Shallow, and Slender
sp.ab: Adieu, good master doctor.

sp.speaker: Caius
sp.ab: By gar, me vill kill de priest; for he speak for a
jack-an-ape to Anne Page.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.ab: Let him die. But first sheathe thy impatience,
throw cold water on thy choler: go about the
fields with me through Frogmore: I will bring
thee where Mistress Anne Page is, at a farm-house
a-feasting; and thou shalt woo her. Cried game? said I
well?

sp.speaker: Caius
sp.ab: By gar, me dank you vor dat: by gar, I love you;
and I shall procure-a you de good guest, de earl, de
knight, de lords, de gentlemen, my patients.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.ab: For the which I will be thy adversary toward Anne
Page. Said I well?

sp.speaker: Caius
sp.ab: By gar, 'tis good; vell said.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.ab: Let us wag, then.

sp.speaker: Caius
sp.ab: Come at my heels, Jack Rugby.

div.head: Act 3, Scene 1
div.stage: Enter SIR HUGH EVANS and SIMPLE.

sp.speaker: Evans
sp.ab: I pray you now, good Master Slender's servingman,
and friend Simple by your name, which way have
you looked for Master Caius, that calls himself doctor
of physic?

sp.speaker: Simple
sp.ab: Marry, sir, the pittie-ward, the park-ward, every way;
old Windsor way, and every way but the town way.

sp.speaker: Evans
sp.ab: I most fehemently desire you you will also look that
way.

sp.speaker: Simple
sp.ab: I will, sir.

sp.speaker: Evans
sp.ab: 'Pless my soul, how full of chollors I am, and
trempling of mind! I shall be glad if he have
deceived me. How melancholies I am! I will knog
his urinals about his knave's costard when I have good
opportunities for the ork. 'Pless my soul!
sp.l: To shallow rivers, to whose falls
Melodious birds sings madrigals;
There will we make our peds of roses,
And a thousand fragrant posies.
To shallow —
sp.ab: Mercy on me! I have a great dispositions to cry.
sp.l: Melodious birds sing madrigals —
When as I sat in Pabylon —
And a thousand vagram posies.
To shallow, etc. Re-enter SIMPLE.

sp.speaker: Simple
sp.ab: Yonder he is coming, this way, Sir Hugh.

sp.speaker: Evans
sp.ab: He's welcome.
sp.l: To shallow rivers, to whose falls —
sp.ab: Heaven prosper the right! What weapons is he?

sp.speaker: Simple
sp.ab: No weapons, sir. There comes my master, Master
Shallow, and another gentleman, from Frogmore, over
the stile, this way.

sp.speaker: Evans
sp.ab: Pray you, give me my gown; or else keep it in your
arms.

sp.speaker: Shallow
sp.ab: How now, master Parson! Good morrow, good Sir
Hugh. Keep a gamester from the dice, and a good
student from his book, and it is wonderful.

sp.speaker: Slender
sp.ab: Ah, sweet Anne Page!

sp.speaker: Page
sp.ab: God save you, good Sir Hugh!

sp.speaker: Evans
sp.ab: God pless you from his mercy sake, all of you

sp.speaker: Shallow
sp.ab: What, the sword and the word! do you study them both,
master parson?

sp.speaker: Page
sp.ab: And youthful still! in your doublet and hose this raw
rheumatic day!

sp.speaker: Evans
sp.ab: There is reasons and causes for it.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.ab: We are come to you to do a good office, master parson.

sp.speaker: Evans
sp.ab: Fery well: what is it?

sp.speaker: Page
sp.ab: Yonder is a most reverend gentleman, who, belike
having received wrong by some person, is at most
odds with his own gravity and patience that ever you
saw.

sp.speaker: Shallow
sp.ab: I have lived fourscore years and upward; I never
heard a man of his place, gravity and learning, so
wide of his own respect.

sp.speaker: Evans
sp.ab: What is he?

sp.speaker: Page
sp.ab: I think you know him; Master Doctor Caius, the
renowned French physician.

sp.speaker: Evans
sp.ab: Got's will, and his passion of my heart! I had as lief
you would tell me of a mess of porridge.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.ab: Why?

sp.speaker: Evans
sp.ab: He has no more knowledge in Hibocrates and Galen,
and he is a knave besides; a cowardly knave as you
would desires to be acquainted withal.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.ab: I warrant you, he's the man should fight with him.

sp.speaker: Slender
sp.ab: O sweet Anne Page!

sp.speaker: Shallow
sp.ab: It appears so by his weapons. Keep them asunder; here
comes Doctor Caius.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.ab: Nay, good master parson, keep in your weapon.

sp.speaker: Shallow
sp.ab: So do you, good master doctor.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.ab: Disarm them, and let them question: let them keep
their limbs whole and hack our English.

sp.speaker: Caius
sp.ab: I pray you, let-a me speak a word with your ear.
Vherefore vill you not meet-a me?

sp.speaker: Evans
sp.ab: Pray you, use your patience: in good time.

sp.speaker: Caius
sp.ab: By gar, you are de coward, de Jack dog, John ape.

sp.speaker: Evans
sp.ab: Pray you, let us not be laughing-stocks to other
men's humours; I desire you in friendship and I
will one way or other make you amends.
I will knog your urinals about your knave's cogscomb
for missing your meetings and appointments.

sp.speaker: Caius
sp.ab: Diable! Jack Rugby, — mine host de Jarteer, — have
I not stay for him to kill him? have I not, at de
place I did appoint?

sp.speaker: Evans
sp.ab: As I am a Christians-soul now, look you, this is
the place appointed: I'll be judgement by mine host of
the Garter.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.ab: Peace, I say, Gallia and Gaul, French and Welsh,
soul-curer and body-curer!

sp.speaker: Caius
sp.ab: Ay, dat is very good; excellent.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.ab: Peace, I say! hear mine host of the Garter. Am
I politic? am I subtle? am I a Machiavel? Shall
I lose my doctor? no; he gives me the potions
and the motions. Shall I lose my parson, my
priest, my Sir Hugh? no: he gives me the proverbs
and the no-verbs. Give me thy hand, terrestial;
so. Give me thy hand, celestial; so. Boys of art,
I have deceived you both; I have directed you to
wrong places: your hearts are mighty, your skins
are whole, and let burnt sack be the issue. Come,
lay their swords to pawn. Follow me, lads of peace;
follow, follow, follow.

sp.speaker: Shallow
sp.ab: Trust me, a mad host. Follow, gentlemen, follow.

sp.speaker: Slender
sp.ab: O sweet Anne Page!
sp.stage: Exeunt Shal., Slen., Page, and Host.

sp.speaker: Caius
sp.ab: Ha, do I perceive dat? have you make-a de sot of us,
ha, ha?

sp.speaker: Evans
sp.ab: This is well; he has made us his vlouting-stog.
I desire you that we may be friends; and let us
knog our prains together to be revenge on this
same scall, scurvy, cogging companion, the host of the
Garter.

sp.speaker: Caius
sp.ab: By gar, with all my heart. He promise to bring me
where is Anne Page; by gar, he deceive me too.

sp.speaker: Evans
sp.ab: Well, I will smite his noddles. Pray you, follow.

div.head: Act 3, Scene 2
div.stage: A street. Enter MISTRESS PAGE and ROBIN.

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.ab: Nay, keep your way, little gallant; you were wont
to be a follower, but now you are a leader.
Whether had you rather lead mine eyes, or eye your
master's heels?

sp.speaker: Robin
sp.ab: I had rather, forsooth, go before you like a man than
follow him like a dwarf.

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.ab: O, you are a flattering boy: now I see you'll be a
courtier.

sp.speaker: Ford
sp.ab: Well met, Mistress Page. Whither go you?

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.ab: Truly, sir, to see your wife. Is she at home?

sp.speaker: Ford
sp.ab: Ay; and as idle as she may hang together, for
want of company. I think, if your husbands were dead,
you two would marry.

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.ab: Be sure of that, — two other husbands.

sp.speaker: Ford
sp.ab: Where had you this pretty weathercock?

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.ab: I cannot tell what the dickens his name is my
husband had him of. What do you call your knight's
name, sirrah?

sp.speaker: Robin
sp.ab: Sir John Falstaff.

sp.speaker: Ford
sp.ab: Sir John Falstaff!

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.ab: He, he; I can never hit on's name. There is such
a league between my goodman and he! Is your wife at
home indeed?

sp.speaker: Ford
sp.ab: Indeed she is.

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.ab: By your leave, sir: I am sick till I see her.

sp.speaker: Ford
sp.ab: Has Page any brains? hath he any eyes? hath he
any thinking? Sure, they sleep; he hath no use
of them. Why, this boy will carry a letter twenty
mile, as easy as a cannon will shoot pointblank
twelve score. He pieces out his wife's inclination;
he gives her folly motion and advantage: and now
she's going to my wife, and Falstaff's boy with
her. A man may hear this shower sing in the wind.
And Falstaff's boy with her! Good plots, they
are laid; and our revolted wives share damnation
together. Well; I will take him, then torture my
wife, pluck the borrowed veil of modesty from
the so-seeming Mistress Page, divulge Page himself
for a secure and wilful Actaeon; and to these
violent proceedings all my neighbours shall cry
aim.
The clock gives me my cue, and my assurance bids
me search: there I shall find Falstaff: I shall
be rather praised for this than mocked; for it
is as positive as the earth is firm that Falstaff is
there: I will go.
sp.stage: Enter PAGE, SHALLOW, SLENDER, HOST, SIR HUGH EVANS, CAIUS, and RUGBY.

sp.speaker: Shallow, Page, c.
sp.ab: Well met, Master Ford.

sp.speaker: Ford
sp.ab: Trust me a good knot: I have good cheer at home; and I
pray you all go with me.

sp.speaker: Shallow
sp.ab: I must excuse myself, Master Ford.

sp.speaker: Slender
sp.ab: And so must I, sir: we have appointed to dine
with Mistress Anne, and I would not break with her for
more money than I'll speak of.

sp.speaker: Shallow
sp.ab: We have lingered about a match between Anne Page
and my cousin Slender, and this day we shall have our
answer.

sp.speaker: Slender
sp.ab: I hope I have your good will, father Page.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.ab: You have, Master Slender; I stand wholly for you: but
my wife, master doctor, is for you altogether.

sp.speaker: Caius
sp.ab: Ay, be-gar; and de maid is love-a me: my nursh-a
Quickly tell me so mush.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.ab: What say you to young Master Fenton? he capers,
he dances, he has eyes of youth, he writes verses,
he speaks holiday, he smells April and May: he
will carry't, he will carry't; 'tis in his buttons; he
will carry't.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.ab: Not by my consent, I promise you. The gentleman
is of no having: he kept company with the wild
prince and Poins; he is of too high a region; he
knows too much. No, he shall not knit a knot in
his fortunes with the finger of my substance: if
he take her, let him take her simply; the wealth
I have waits on my consent, and my consent goes not
that way.

sp.speaker: Ford
sp.ab: I beseech you heartily, some of you go home with
me to dinner: besides your cheer, you shall have
sport; I will show you a monster. Master doctor,
you shall go; so shall you, Master Page; and you, Sir
Hugh.

sp.speaker: Shallow
sp.ab: Well, fare you well: we shall have the freer wooing at
Master Page's.

sp.speaker: Caius
sp.ab: Go home, John Rugby: I come anon.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.ab: Farewell, my hearts: I will to my honest knight
Falstaff, and drink canary with him.

sp.speaker: Ford
sp.ab: I think I shall drink in pipe-wine first with him:
I'll make him dance. Will you go, gentles?

sp.speaker: All
sp.ab: Have with you to see this monster.

div.head: Act 3, Scene 3
div.stage: Enter MISTRESS FORD and MISTRESS PAGE.

sp.speaker: Mistress Ford
sp.ab: What, John! What, Robert!

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.ab: Quickly, quickly! Is the buck-basket —

sp.speaker: Mistress Ford
sp.ab: I warrant. What, Robin, I say!

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.ab: Come, come, come.

sp.speaker: Mistress Ford
sp.ab: Here, set it down.

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.ab: Give your men the charge; we must be brief.

sp.speaker: Mistress Ford
sp.ab: Marry, as I told you before, John and Robert, be
ready here hard by in the brew-house: and when
I suddenly call you, come forth, and without any
pause or staggering take this basket on your
shoulders: that done, trudge with it in all haste,
and carry it among the whitsters in Datchet-mead,
and there empty it in the muddy ditch close by the
Thames side.

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.ab: You will do it?

sp.speaker: Mistress Ford
sp.ab: I ha' told them over and over; they lack no direction.
Be gone, and come when you are called.

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.ab: Here comes little Robin.

sp.speaker: Mistress Ford
sp.ab: How now, my eyas-musket! what news with you?

sp.speaker: Robin
sp.ab: My master, Sir John, is come in at your back door,
Mistress Ford, and requests your company.

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.ab: You little Jack-a-Lent, have you been true to us?

sp.speaker: Robin
sp.ab: Ay, I'll be sworn. My master knows not of your
being here and hath threatened to put me into
everlasting liberty if I tell you of it; for he swears
he'll turn me away.

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.ab: Thou'rt a good boy: this secrecy of thine shall
be a tailor to thee and shall make thee a new doublet
and hose. I'll go hide me.

sp.speaker: Mistress Ford
sp.ab: Do so. Go tell thy master I am alone.
Mistress Page, remember you your cue.

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.ab: I warrant thee; if I do not act it, hiss me.

sp.speaker: Mistress Ford
sp.ab: Go to, then: we'll use this unwholesome humidity,
this gross watery pumpion; we'll teach him to know
turtles from jays.

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: Have I caught thee, my heavenly jewel? Why, now
let me die, for I have lived long enough: this
is the period of my ambition: O this blessed hour!

sp.speaker: Mistress Ford
sp.ab: O sweet Sir John!

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: Mistress Ford, I cannot cog, I cannot prate,
Mistress Ford. Now shall I sin in my wish: I
would thy husband were dead: I'll speak it before the
best lord; I would make thee my lady.

sp.speaker: Mistress Ford
sp.ab: I your lady, Sir John! alas, I should be a pitiful
lady!

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: Let the court of France show me such another. I
see how thine eye would emulate the diamond: thou
hast the right arched beauty of the brow that
becomes the ship-tire, the tire-valiant, or any tire
of Venetian admittance.

sp.speaker: Mistress Ford
sp.ab: A plain kerchief, Sir John: my brows become nothing
else; nor that well neither.

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: By the Lord. thou art a tyrant to say so: thou
wouldst make an absolute courtier; and the firm
fixture of thy foot would give an excellent motion
to thy gait in a semicircled farthingale. I see
what thou wert, if Fortune thy foe were not, Nature
thy friend. Come, thou canst not hide it.

sp.speaker: Mistress Ford
sp.ab: Believe me, there's no such thing in me.

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: What made me love thee? let that persuade thee
there's something extraordinary in thee. Come,
I cannot cog and say thou art this and that, like
a many of these lisping hawthorn buds, that come
like women in men's apparel, and smell like
Bucklersbury in simple time; I cannot: but I love
thee; none but thee; and thou deserv'st it.

sp.speaker: Mistress Ford
sp.ab: Do not betray me, sir. I fear you love Mistress Page.

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: Thou mightst as well say I love to walk by the
Counter-gate, which is as hateful to me as the reek of
a lime-kiln.

sp.speaker: Mistress Ford
sp.ab: Well, heaven knows how I love you; and you shall one
day find it.

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: Keep in that mind; I'll deserve it.

sp.speaker: Mistress Ford
sp.ab: Nay, I must tell you, so you do; or else I could not
be in that mind.

sp.speaker: Robin
sp.ab: Mistress Ford, Mistress Ford! here's Mistress
Page at the door sweating and blowing and looking
wildly, and would needs speak with you presently.

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: She shall not see me: I will ensconce me behind the
arras.

sp.speaker: Mistress Ford
sp.ab: Pray you, do so: she's a very tattling woman.
What's the matter? how now!

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.ab: O Mistress Ford, what have you done? You're shamed, y'
are overthrown, y' are undone for ever!

sp.speaker: Mistress Ford
sp.ab: What's the matter, good Mistress Page?

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.ab: O well-a-day, Mistress Ford! having an honest
man to your husband, to give him such cause of
suspicion!

sp.speaker: Mistress Ford
sp.ab: What cause of suspicion?

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.ab: What cause of suspicion! Out upon you! how am I
mistook in you.

sp.speaker: Mistress Ford
sp.ab: Why, alas, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.ab: Your husband's coming hither, woman, with all
the officers in Windsor, to search for a gentleman
that he says is here now in the house by your
consent, to take an ill advantage of his absence: you
are undone.

sp.speaker: Mistress Ford
sp.ab: 'Tis not so, I hope.

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.ab: Pray heaven it be not so, that you have such a
man here! but 'tis most certain your husband's
coming, with half Windsor at his heels, to search
for such a one. I come before to tell you. If
you know yourself clear, why, I am glad of it;
but if you have a friend here, convey, convey
him out. Be not amazed; call all your senses to
you; defend your reputation, or bid farewell to your
good life for ever.

sp.speaker: Mistress Ford
sp.ab: What shall I do? There is a gentleman my dear
friend; and I fear not mine own shame so much as
his peril: I had rather than a thousand pound he were
out of the house.

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.ab: For shame! never stand “you had rather” and “you
had rather:” your husband's here at hand; bethink
you of some conveyance; in the house you cannot
hide him. O, how have you deceived me! Look, here
is a basket: if he be of any reasonable stature,
he may creep in here; and throw foul linen upon
him, as if it were going to bucking: or — it is
whiting-time — send him by your two men to Datchet-mead.

sp.speaker: Mistress Ford
sp.ab: He's too big to go in there. What shall I do?

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: Let me see't, let me see't, O, let me see't! I'll in,
I'll in. Follow your friend's counsel. I'll in.

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.ab: What, Sir John Falstaff! Are these your letters,
knight?

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: I love thee. Help me away. Let me creep in here. I'll
never —
sp.stage: Gets into the basket; they cover him with foul linen.

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.ab: Help to cover your master, boy. Call your men,
Mistress Ford. You dissembling knight!

sp.speaker: Mistress Ford
sp.ab: What, John! Robert! John!
Go take up these clothes here quickly. Where's
the cowl-staff? look, how you drumble! Carry them to
the laundress in Datchet-mead; quickly, come.
sp.stage: Enter FORD, PAGE, CAIUS, and SIR HUGH EVANS.

sp.speaker: Ford
sp.ab: Pray you, come near: if I suspect without cause,
why then make sport at me; then let me be your jest; I
deserve it. How now! whither bear you this?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.ab: To the laundress, forsooth.

sp.speaker: Mistress Ford
sp.ab: Why, what have you to do whither they bear it? You
were best meddle with buckwashing.

sp.speaker: Ford
sp.ab: Buck! I would I could wash myself of the buck!
Buck, buck, buck! Ay, buck; I warrant you, buck;
and of the season too, it shall appear.
Gentlemen, I have dreamed tonight; I'll tell you
my dream. Here, here, here be my keys: ascend my
chambers; search, seek, find out: I'll warrant
we'll unkennel the fox. Let me stop this way first.
So, now uncape.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.ab: Good Master Ford, be contented; you wrong yourself too
much.

sp.speaker: Ford
sp.ab: True, Master Page. Up, gentlemen; you shall see sport
anon: follow me. gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Evans
sp.ab: This is fery fantastical humours and jealousies.

sp.speaker: Caius
sp.ab: By gar, 'tis no the fashion of France; it is not
jealous in France.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.ab: Nay, follow him, gentlemen; see the issue of his
search.

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
