sp.ab: Is there not a double excellency in this?

sp.speaker: Mistress Ford
sp.ab: I know not which pleases me better, that my husband is
deceived, or Sir John.

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.ab: What a taking was he in when your husband asked who
was in the basket!

sp.speaker: Mistress Ford
sp.ab: I am half afraid he will have need of washing;
so throwing him into the water will do him a benefit.

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.ab: Hang him, dishonest rascal! I would all of the same
strain were in the same distress.

sp.speaker: Mistress Ford
sp.ab: I think my husband hath some special suspicion
of Falstaff's being here; for I never saw him so gross
in his jealousy till now.

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.ab: I will lay a plot to try that; and we will yet
have more tricks with Falstaff: his dissolute disease
will scarce obey this medicine.

sp.speaker: Mistress Ford
sp.ab: Shall we send that foolish carrion, Mistress
Quickly, to him, and excuse his throwing into
the water; and give him another hope, to betray him to
another punishment?

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.ab: We will do it: let him be sent for to-morrow, eight a'
clock, to have amends.
sp.stage: Re-enter FORD, PAGE, CAIUS, and SIR HUGH EVANS.

sp.speaker: Ford
sp.ab: I cannot find him: may be the knave bragged of that he
could not compass.

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.ab: Heard you that?

sp.speaker: Mistress Ford
sp.ab: You use me well, Master Ford, do you?

sp.speaker: Ford
sp.ab: Ay, I do so.

sp.speaker: Mistress Ford
sp.ab: Heaven make you better than your thoughts!

sp.speaker: Ford
sp.ab: Amen!

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.ab: You do yourself mighty wrong, Master Ford.

sp.speaker: Ford
sp.ab: Ay, ay; I must bear it.

sp.speaker: Evans
sp.ab: If there be any pody in the house and in the
chambers, and in the coffers, and in the presses,
heaven forgive my sins at the day of judgement!

sp.speaker: Caius
sp.ab: By gar, nor I too: there is no-bodies.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.ab: Fie, fie, Master Ford! are you not ashamed? What
spirit, what devil suggests this imagination? I
would not ha' your distemper in this kind for the
wealth of Windsor Castle.

sp.speaker: Ford
sp.ab: 'Tis my fault, Master Page: I suffer for it.

sp.speaker: Evans
sp.ab: You suffer for a pad conscience: your wife is as
honest a 'omans as I will desires among five thousand,
and five hundred too.

sp.speaker: Caius
sp.ab: By gar, I see 'tis an honest woman.

sp.speaker: Ford
sp.ab: Well, I promised you a dinner. Come, come, walk
in the Park: I pray you, pardon me; I will
hereafter make known to you why I have done this.
Come, wife; come, Mistress Page. I pray you pardon me;
pray heartily, pardon me.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.ab: Let's go in, gentlemen; but, trust me, we'll mock
him. I do invite you to-morrow morning to my
house to breakfast: after, we'll a-birding
together; I have a fine hawk for the bush. Shall it be
so?

sp.speaker: Ford
sp.ab: Any thing.

sp.speaker: Evans
sp.ab: If there is one, I shall make two in the company.

sp.speaker: Caius
sp.ab: If there be one or two, I shall make-a the turd.

sp.speaker: Ford
sp.ab: Pray you, go, Master Page.

sp.speaker: Evans
sp.ab: I pray you now, remembrance to-morrow on the lousy
knave, mine host.

sp.speaker: Caius
sp.ab: Dat is good; by gar, with all my heart!

sp.speaker: Evans
sp.ab: A lousy knave, to have his gibes and his mockeries!

sp.speaker: Fenton
sp.l: I see I cannot get thy father's love;
Therefore no more turn me to him, sweet Nan.

sp.speaker: Anne
sp.l: Alas, how then?

sp.speaker: Fenton
sp.l: Why, thou must be thyself.
He doth object I am too great of birth;
And that, my state being galled with my expense,
I seek to heal it only by his wealth:
Besides these, other bars he lays before me,
My riots past, my wild societies;
And tells me 'tis a thing impossible
I should love thee but as a property.

sp.speaker: Anne
sp.l: May be he tells you true.

sp.speaker: Fenton
sp.l: No, heaven so speed me in my time to come!
Albeit I will confess thy father's wealth
Was the first motive that I wooed thee, Anne:
Yet, wooing thee, I found thee of more value
Than stamps in gold or sums in sealed bags;
And 'tis the very riches of thyself
That now I aim at.

sp.speaker: Anne
sp.l: Gentle Master Fenton,
Yet seek my father's love; still seek it, sir:
If opportunity and humblest suit
Cannot attain it, why, then, — hark you hither! They converse apart. Enter SHALLOW, SLENDER, and MISTRESS QUICKLY.

sp.speaker: Shallow
sp.ab: Break their talk, Mistress Quickly: my kinsman shall
speak for himself.

sp.speaker: Slender
sp.ab: I'll make a shaft or a bolt on't: 'slid, 'tis but
venturing.

sp.speaker: Shallow
sp.ab: Be not dismayed.

sp.speaker: Slender
sp.ab: No, she shall not dismay me: I care not for that, but
that I am afeard.

sp.speaker: Quickly
sp.ab: Hark ye; Master Slender would speak a word with you.

sp.speaker: Anne
sp.l: I come to him. Aside
This is my father's choice.
O, what a world of vile ill-favoured faults
Looks handsome in three hundred pounds a year!

sp.speaker: Quickly
sp.ab: And how does good Master Fenton? Pray you, a word with
you.

sp.speaker: Shallow
sp.ab: She's coming; to her, coz. O boy, thou hadst a father!

sp.speaker: Slender
sp.ab: I had a father, Mistress Anne; my uncle can tell
you good jests of him. Pray you, uncle, tell
Mistress Anne the jest, how my father stole two geese
out of a pen, good uncle.

sp.speaker: Shallow
sp.ab: Mistress Anne, my cousin loves you.

sp.speaker: Slender
sp.ab: Ay, that I do: as well as I love any woman in
Gloucestershire.

sp.speaker: Shallow
sp.ab: He will maintain you like a gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Slender
sp.ab: Ay, that I will, come cut and long-tail, under the
degree of a squire.

sp.speaker: Shallow
sp.ab: He will make you a hundred and fifty pounds jointure.

sp.speaker: Anne
sp.ab: Good Master Shallow, let him woo for himself.

sp.speaker: Shallow
sp.ab: Marry, I thank you for it; I thank you for that good
comfort. She calls you, coz: I'll leave you.

sp.speaker: Anne
sp.ab: Now, Master Slender, —

sp.speaker: Slender
sp.ab: Now, good Mistress Anne, —

sp.speaker: Anne
sp.ab: What is your will?

sp.speaker: Slender
sp.ab: My will! 'od's heartlings, that's a pretty jest
indeed! I ne'er made my will yet, I thank heaven;
I am not such a sickly creature, I give heaven praise.

sp.speaker: Anne
sp.ab: I mean, Master Slender, what would you with me?

sp.speaker: Slender
sp.ab: Truly, for mine own part, I would little or
nothing with you. Your father and my uncle hath
made motions: if it be my luck, so; if not, happy
man be his dole! They can tell you how things go
better than I can: you may ask your father; here he
comes.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: Now, Master Slender: love him, daughter Anne.
Why, how now! what does Master Fenton here?
You wrong me, sir, thus still to haunt my house:
I told you, sir, my daughter is disposed of.

sp.speaker: Fenton
sp.l: Nay, Master Page, be not impatient.

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.l: Good Master Fenton, come not to my child.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: She is no match for you.

sp.speaker: Fenton
sp.l: Sir, will you hear me?

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: No, good Master Fenton.
Come, Master Shallow; come, son Slender in.
Knowing my mind, you wrong me, Master Fenton. Exeunt Page, Shal., and Slen.

sp.speaker: Quickly
sp.l: Speak to Mistress Page.

sp.speaker: Fenton
sp.l: Good Mistress Page, for that I love your daughter
In such a righteous fashion as I do,
Perforce, against all checks, rebukes and manners,
I must advance the colours of my love
And not retire: let me have your good will.

sp.speaker: Anne
sp.l: Good mother, do not marry me to yond fool.

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.l: I mean it not; I seek you a better husband.

sp.speaker: Quickly
sp.l: That's my master, master doctor.

sp.speaker: Anne
sp.l: Alas, I had rather be set quick i' the earth
And bowled to death with turnips!

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.l: Come, trouble not yourself. Good Master Fenton,
I will not be your friend nor enemy:
My daughter will I question how she loves you,
And as I find her, so am I affected.
Till then farewell, sir: she must needs go in;
Her father will be angry.

sp.speaker: Fenton
sp.l: Farewell, gentle mistress; farewell, Nan. Exeunt Mrs. Page and Anne.

sp.speaker: Quickly
sp.ab: This is my doing, now: “Nay,” said I, “will you
cast away your child on a fool, and a physician? Look
on Master Fenton:” this is my doing

sp.speaker: Fenton
sp.l: I thank thee; and I pray thee, once to-night
Give my sweet Nan this ring: there's for thy pains.

sp.speaker: Quickly
sp.ab: Now heaven send thee good fortune!
A kind heart he hath; a woman would run through
fire and water for such a kind heart. But yet I
would my master had Mistress Anne; or I would
Master Slender had her; or, in sooth, I would
Master Fenton had her: I will do what I can for
them all three; for so I have promised, and I'll
be as good as my word; but speciously for Master
Fenton. Well, I must of another errand to Sir
John Falstaff from my two mistresses: what a beast am
I to slack it!

div.head: Act 3, Scene 5
div.stage: A room in the Garter Inn.

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: Bardolph, I say, —

sp.speaker: Bardolph
sp.ab: Here, sir.

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: Go fetch me a quart of sack; put a toast in't.
Have I lived to be carried in a basket, like a
barrow of butcher's offal, and to be thrown in
the Thames? Well, if I be served such another
trick, I'll have my brains ta'en out and buttered,
and give them to a dog for a new-year's gift.
The rogues slighted me into the river with as
little remorse as they would have drowned a blind
bitch's puppies, fifteen i' the litter: and you
may know by my size that I have a kind of alacrity
in sinking; if the bottom were as deep as hell,
I should down. I had been drowned, but that the
shore was shelvy and shallow, — a death that I
abhor; for the water swells a man; and what a
thing should I have been when I had been swelled! I
should have been a mountain of mummy.

sp.speaker: Bardolph
sp.ab: Here's Mistress Quickly, sir, to speak with you.

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: Come, let me pour in some sack to the Thames
water; for my belly's as cold as if I had swallowed
snowballs for pills to cool the reins. Call her in.

sp.speaker: Bardolph
sp.ab: Come in, woman!

sp.speaker: Quickly
sp.ab: By your leave; I cry you mercy: give your worship good
morrow.

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: Take away these chalices. Go brew me a pottle of sack
finely.

sp.speaker: Bardolph
sp.ab: With eggs, sir?

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: Simple of itself; I'll no pullet-sperm in my brewage.
How now!

sp.speaker: Quickly
sp.ab: Marry, sir, I come to your worship from Mistress Ford.

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: Mistress Ford! I have had ford enough; I was thrown
into the ford; I have my belly full of ford.

sp.speaker: Quickly
sp.ab: Alas the day! good heart, that was not her fault:
she does so take on with her men; they mistook their
erection.

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: So did I mine, to build upon a foolish woman's
promise.

sp.speaker: Quickly
sp.ab: Well, she laments, sir, for it, that it would
yearn your heart to see it. Her husband goes this
morning a-birding; she desires you once more to
come to her between eight and nine: I must carry
her word quickly: she'll make you amends, I warrant
you.

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: Well, I will visit her: tell her so; and bid her
think what a man is: let her consider his frailty, and
then judge of my merit.

sp.speaker: Quickly
sp.ab: I will tell her.

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: Do so. Between nine and ten, sayest thou?

sp.speaker: Quickly
sp.ab: Eight and nine, sir.

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: Well, be gone: I will not miss her.

sp.speaker: Quickly
sp.ab: Peace be with you, sir.

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: I marvel I hear not of Master Brook; he sent me
word to stay within: i like his money well. O, here he
comes.

sp.speaker: Ford
sp.ab: Bless you, sir!

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: Now, Master Brook, you come to know what hath passed
between me and Ford's wife?

sp.speaker: Ford
sp.ab: That, indeed, Sir John, is my business.

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: Master Brook, I will not lie to you; I was at her
house the hour she appointed me.

sp.speaker: Ford
sp.ab: And sped you, sir?

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: Very ill-favouredly, Master Brook.

sp.speaker: Ford
sp.ab: How so, sir? Did she change her determination?

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: No, Master Brook; but the peaking Cornuto her
husband, Master Brook, dwelling in a continual
'larum of jealousy, comes me in the instant of
our encounter, after we had embraced, kissed,
protested, and, as it were, spoke the prologue
of our comedy; and at his heels a rabble of his
companions, thither provoked and instigated by
his distemper, and, forsooth, to search his house for
his wife's love.

sp.speaker: Ford
sp.ab: What, while you were there?

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: While I was there.

sp.speaker: Ford
sp.ab: And did he search for you, and could not find you?

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: You shall hear. As good luck would have it, comes
in one Mistress Page; gives intelligence of Ford's
approach; and, in her invention and Ford's wife's
distraction, they conveyed me into a buck-basket.

sp.speaker: Ford
sp.ab: A buck-basket!

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: By the Lord, a buck-basket! rammed me in with
foul shirts and smocks, socks, foul stockings,
greasy napkins; that, Master Brook, there was
the rankest compound of villainous smell that ever
offended nostril.

sp.speaker: Ford
sp.ab: And how long lay you there?

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: Nay, you shall hear, Master Brook, what I have
suffered to bring this woman to evil for your
good. Being thus crammed in the basket, a couple
of Ford's knaves, his hinds, were called forth
by their mistress to carry me in the name of foul
clothes to Datchet-lane: they took me on their
shoulders; met the jealous knave their master in
the door, who asked them once or twice what they
had in their basket: I quaked for fear, lest the
lunatic knave would have searched it; but fate,
ordaining he should be a cuckold, held his hand.
Well: on went he for a search, and away went I
for foul clothes. But mark the sequel, Master
Brook: I suffered the pangs of three several
deaths; first, an intolerable fright, to be
detected with a jealous rotten bell-wether; next,
to be compassed, like a good bilbo, in the
circumference of a peck, hilt to point, heel to
head; and then, to be stopped in, like a strong
distillation, with stinking clothes that fretted
in their own grease. think of that, — a man of my
kidney, — think of that, — that am as subject to
heat as butter; a man of continual dissolution
and thaw: it was a miracle to scape suffocation.
And in the height of this bath, when I was more
than half stewed in grease, like a Dutch dish,
to be thrown into the Thames, and cooled,
glowing-hot, in that surge, like a horse-shoe;
think of that, — hissing-hot, — think of that, Master
Brook.

sp.speaker: Ford
sp.ab: In good sadness, sir, I am sorry that for my sake
you have suffered all this. My suit then is desperate;
you'll undertake her no more?

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: Master Brook, I will be thrown into Etna, as I
have been into Thames, ere I will leave her thus.
Her husband is this morning gone a-birding: I
have received from her another embassy of meeting;
'twixt eight and nine is the hour, Master Brook.

sp.speaker: Ford
sp.ab: 'Tis past eight already, sir.

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: Is it? I will then address me to my appointment.
Come to me at your convenient leisure, and you
shall know how I speed; and the conclusion shall
be crowned with your enjoying her. Adieu. You
shall have her, Master Brook; Master Brook, you shall
cuckold Ford.

sp.speaker: Ford
sp.ab: Hum! ha! is this a vision? is this a dream? do
I sleep? Master Ford, awake! awake, Master Ford!
there's a hole made in your best coat, Master
Ford. This 'tis to be married! this 'tis to have
linen and buck-baskets! Well, I will proclaim
myself what I am: I will now take the lecher; he
is at my house; he cannot scape me; 'tis impossible
he should; he cannot creep into a halfpenny purse,
nor into a pepper-box: but, lest the devil that
guides him should aid him, I will search impossible
places. Though what I am I cannot avoid, yet to
be what I would not shall not make me tame: if
I have horns to make one mad, let the proverb go with
me: I'll be horn-mad.

div.head: Act 4, Scene 1
div.stage: Enter MISTRESS PAGE, MISTRESS QUICKLY, and WILLIAM.

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.ab: Is he at Master Ford's already, think'st thou?

sp.speaker: Quickly
sp.ab: Sure he is by this, or will be presently: but,
truly, he is very courageous mad about his throwing
into the water. Mistress Ford desires you to come
suddenly.

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.ab: I'll be with her by and by; I'll but bring my
young man here to school. Look, where his master
comes; 'tis a playing-day, I see.
How now. Sir Hugh! no school to-day?

sp.speaker: Evans
sp.ab: No; Master Slender is let the boys leave to play.

sp.speaker: Quickly
sp.ab: Blessing of his heart!

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.ab: Sir Hugh, my husband says my son profits nothing
in the world at his book. I pray you, ask him some
questions in his accidence —

sp.speaker: Evans
sp.ab: Come hither, William; hold up your head; come.

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.ab: Come on, sirrah; hold up your head; answer your
master, be not afraid.

sp.speaker: Evans
sp.ab: William, how many numbers is in nouns?

sp.speaker: William Page
sp.ab: Two.

sp.speaker: Quickly
sp.ab: Truly. I thought there had been one number more,
because they say, “'Od's nouns.”

sp.speaker: Evans
sp.ab: Peace your tattlings! What is “fair,” William?

sp.speaker: William Page
sp.ab: Pulcher.

sp.speaker: Quickly
sp.ab: Polecats! there are fairer things than polecats, sure.

sp.speaker: Evans
sp.ab: You are a very simplicity 'oman; I pray you, peace.
What is “lapis,” William?

sp.speaker: William Page
sp.ab: A stone.

sp.speaker: Evans
sp.ab: And what is “a stone,” William?

sp.speaker: William Page
sp.ab: A pebble.

sp.speaker: Evans
sp.ab: No, it is “lapis:” I pray you, remember in your prain.

sp.speaker: William Page
sp.ab: Lapis.

sp.speaker: Evans
sp.ab: That is a good William. What is he, William, that does
lend articles?

sp.speaker: William Page
sp.ab: Articles are borrowed of the pronoun, and be thus
declined, Singulariter, nominativo, hic, haec, hoc.

sp.speaker: Evans
sp.ab: Nominativo, hig, hag, hog; pray you, mark: genitivo,
hujus. Well what is your accusative case?

sp.speaker: William Page
sp.ab: Accusativo, hinc.

sp.speaker: Evans
sp.ab: I pray you, have your remembrance, child; accusativo,
hung, hang, hog.

sp.speaker: Quickly
sp.ab: “Hang-hog” is Latin for bacon, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Evans
sp.ab: Leave your prabbles. 'oman. What is the focative case,
William?

sp.speaker: William Page
sp.ab: O, — vocativo, O.

sp.speaker: Evans
sp.ab: Remember, William; focative is caret.

sp.speaker: Quickly
sp.ab: And that's a good root.

sp.speaker: Evans
sp.ab: 'Oman, forbear.

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.ab: Peace!

sp.speaker: Evans
sp.ab: What is your genitive case plural, William?

sp.speaker: William Page
sp.ab: Genitive case!

sp.speaker: Evans
sp.ab: Ay.

sp.speaker: William Page
sp.ab: Genitivo, — horum, harum, horum.

sp.speaker: Quickly
sp.ab: Vengeance of Jenny's case! fie on her! never name her,
child, if she be a whore.

sp.speaker: Evans
sp.ab: For shame, 'oman.

sp.speaker: Quickly
sp.ab: You do ill to teach the child such words: he
teaches him to hick and to hack, which they'll
do fast enough of themselves, and to call “horum:” fie
upon you!

sp.speaker: Evans
sp.ab: 'Oman, art thou lunatics? hast thou no understandings
for thy cases and the numbers of the genders?
Thou art as foolish Christian creatures as I would
desires.

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.ab: Prithee, hold thy peace.

sp.speaker: Evans
sp.ab: Show me now, William, some declensions of your
pronouns.

sp.speaker: William Page
sp.ab: Forsooth, I have forgot.

sp.speaker: Evans
sp.ab: It is qui, quae, quod: if you forget your “quies,”
your “quaes,” and your “quods,” you must be preeches.
Go your ways, and play; go.

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.ab: He is a better scholar than I thought he was.

sp.speaker: Evans
sp.ab: He is a good sprag memory. Farewell, Mistress Page.

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.ab: Adieu, good Sir Hugh.
Get you home, boy. Come, we stay too long.

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: Mistress Ford, your sorrow hath eaten up my
sufferance. I see you are obsequious in your
love, and I profess requital to a hair's breadth;
not only, Mistress Ford, in the simple office of
love, but in all the accoutrement, complement
and ceremony of it. But are you sure of your husband
now?

sp.speaker: Mistress Ford
sp.ab: He's a-birding, sweet Sir John.

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.ab: What, ho, gossip Ford! what, ho!

sp.speaker: Mistress Ford
sp.ab: Step into the chamber, Sir John.

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.ab: How now, sweet heart! who's at home besides yourself?

sp.speaker: Mistress Ford
sp.ab: Why, none but mine own people.

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.ab: Indeed!

sp.speaker: Mistress Ford
sp.ab: No, certainly.
Speak louder.

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.ab: Truly, I am so glad you have nobody here.

sp.speaker: Mistress Ford
sp.ab: Why?

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.ab: Why, woman, your husband is in his old lines
again: he so takes on yonder with my husband; so
rails against all married mankind; so curses all
Eve's daughters, of what complexion soever; and
so buffets himself on the forehead, crying, “Peer
out, peer out!” that any madness I ever yet beheld
seemed but tameness, civility and patience, to
this his distemper he is in now: I am glad the fat
knight is not here.

sp.speaker: Mistress Ford
sp.ab: Why, does he talk of him?

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.ab: Of none but him; and swears he was carried out,
the last time he searched for him, in a basket;
protests to my husband he is now here, and hath
drawn him and the rest of their company from
their sport to make another experiment of his
suspicion: but I am glad the knight is not here; now
he shall see his own foolery.

sp.speaker: Mistress Ford
sp.ab: How near is he, Mistress Page?

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.ab: Hard by; at street end; he will be here anon.

sp.speaker: Mistress Ford
sp.ab: I am undone! The knight is here.

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.ab: Why then you are utterly shamed, and he's but a
dead man. What a woman are you! — Away with him, away
with him! better shame than murder.

sp.speaker: Mistress Ford
sp.ab: Which way should he go? how should I bestow him? Shall
I put him into the basket again?

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: No, I'll come no more i' the basket. May I not go out
ere he come?

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.ab: Alas, three of Master Ford's brothers watch the
door with pistols, that none shall issue out;
otherwise you might slip away ere he came. But what
make you here?

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: What shall I do? I'll creep up into the chimney.

sp.speaker: Mistress Ford
sp.ab: There they always use to discharge their
birding-pieces. Creep into the kiln-hole.

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: Where is it?

sp.speaker: Mistress Ford
sp.ab: He will seek there, on my word. Neither press,
coffer, chest, trunk, well, vault, but he hath
an abstract for the remembrance of such places,
and goes to them by his note: there is no hiding you
in the house.

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: I'll go out then.

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.ab: If you go out in your own semblance, you die, Sir
John. Unless you go out disguised —

sp.speaker: Mistress Ford
sp.ab: How might we disguise him?

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.ab: Alas the day, I know not! There is no woman's
gown big enough for him; otherwise he might put on a
hat, a muffler and a kerchief, and so escape.

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: Good hearts, devise something; any extremity rather
than a mischief.

sp.speaker: Mistress Ford
sp.ab: My maid's aunt, the fat woman of Brentford, has a gown
above.

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.ab: On my word, it will serve him; she's as big as
he is: and there's her thrummed hat and her muffler
too. Run up, Sir John.

sp.speaker: Mistress Ford
sp.ab: Go, go, sweet Sir John: Mistress Page and I will look
some linen for your head.

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.ab: Quick, quick! we'll come dress you straight: put on
the gown the while.

sp.speaker: Mistress Ford
sp.ab: I would my husband would meet him in this shape:
he cannot abide the old woman of Brentford; he
swears she's a witch; forbade her my house and hath
threatened to beat her.

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.ab: Heaven guide him to thy husband's cudgel, and the
devil guide his cudgel afterwards!

sp.speaker: Mistress Ford
sp.ab: But is my husband coming?

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.ab: Ay, in good sadness, is he; and talks of the basket
too, howsoever he hath had intelligence.

sp.speaker: Mistress Ford
sp.ab: We'll try that; for I'll appoint my men to carry
the basket again, to meet him at the door with it, as
they did last time.

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.ab: Nay, but he'll be here presently: let's go dress him
like the witch of Brentford.

sp.speaker: Mistress Ford
sp.ab: I'll first direct my men what they shall do with
the basket. Go up; I'll bring linen for him straight.

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.ab: Hang him, dishonest varlet! we cannot misuse him
enough.
sp.l: We'll leave a proof, by that which we will do,
Wives may be merry, and yet honest too:
We do not act that often jest and laugh;
'Tis old, but true, Still swine eats all the draff. Exit. Re-enter MISTRESS FORD with two Servants.

sp.speaker: Mistress Ford
sp.ab: Go, sirs, take the basket again on your shoulders:
your master is hard at door; if he bid you set it
down, obey him: quickly, dispatch.

sp.speaker: First Servant
sp.ab: Come, come, take it up.

sp.speaker: Second Servant
sp.ab: Pray heaven it be not full of knight again.

sp.speaker: First Servant
sp.ab: I hope not; I had lief as bear so much lead.
sp.stage: Enter FORD, PAGE, SHALLOW, CAIUS, and SIR HUGH EVANS.

sp.speaker: Ford
sp.ab: Ay, but if it prove true, Master Page, have you
any way then to unfool me again? Set down the
basket, villain! Somebody call my wife. Youth in
a basket! O you panderly rascals! there's a knot,
a ging, a pack, a conspiracy against me: now
shall the devil be shamed. What, wife, I say!
Come, come forth! Behold what honest clothes you send
forth to bleaching!

sp.speaker: Page
sp.ab: Why, this passes, Master Ford; you are not to go loose
any longer; you must be pinioned.

sp.speaker: Evans
sp.ab: Why, this is lunatics! this is mad as a mad dog.

sp.speaker: Shallow
sp.ab: Indeed, Master Ford, this is not well, indeed.

sp.speaker: Ford
sp.ab: So say I too, sir.
Come hither, Mistress Ford; Mistress Ford, the
honest woman, the modest wife, the virtuous
creature, that hath the jealous fool to her husband! I
suspect without cause, mistress, do I?

sp.speaker: Mistress Ford
sp.ab: Heaven be my witness you do, if you suspect me in any
dishonesty.

sp.speaker: Ford
sp.ab: Well said, brazen-face! hold it out. Come forth,
sirrah!
sp.stage: Pulling clothes out of the basket.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.ab: This passes!

sp.speaker: Mistress Ford
sp.ab: Are you not ashamed? let the clothes alone.

sp.speaker: Ford
sp.ab: I shall find you anon.

sp.speaker: Evans
sp.ab: 'Tis unreasonable! Will you take up your wife's
clothes? Come away.

sp.speaker: Ford
sp.ab: Empty the basket, I say!

sp.speaker: Mistress Ford
sp.ab: Why, man, why?

sp.speaker: Ford
sp.ab: Master Page, as I am a man, there was one conveyed
out of my house yesterday in this basket: why
may not he be there again? in my house I am sure
he is: my intelligence is true; my jealousy is
reasonable. Pluck me out all the linen.

sp.speaker: Mistress Ford
sp.ab: If you find a man there, he shall die a flea's death.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.ab: Here's no man.

sp.speaker: Shallow
sp.ab: By my fidelity, this is not well, Master Ford; this
wrongs you.

sp.speaker: Evans
sp.ab: Master Ford, you must pray, and not follow the
imaginations of your own heart: this is jealousies.

sp.speaker: Ford
sp.ab: Well, he's not here I seek for.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.ab: No, nor no where else but in your brain.

sp.speaker: Ford
sp.ab: Help to search my house this one time. If I find
not what I seek show no colour for my extremity;
let me for ever be your table-sport; let them
say of me, “As jealous as Ford, that searched a
hollow walnut for his wife's leman.” Satisfy me once
more; once more search with me.

sp.speaker: Mistress Ford
sp.ab: What, ho, Mistress Page! come you and the old woman
down; my husband will come into the chamber.

sp.speaker: Ford
sp.ab: Old woman! what old woman's that?

sp.speaker: Mistress Ford
sp.ab: Why, it is my maid's aunt of Brentford.

sp.speaker: Ford
sp.ab: A witch, a quean, an old cozening quean! Have I
not forbid her my house? She comes of errands,
does she? We are simple men; we do not know what's
brought to pass under the profession of
fortune-telling. She works by charms, by spells,
by the figure, and such daubery as this is, beyond
our element: we know nothing. Come down, you witch,
you hag, you; come down, I say!

sp.speaker: Mistress Ford
sp.ab: Nay, good, sweet husband! Good gentlemen, let him not
strike the old woman.
sp.stage: Re-enter FALSTAFF in woman's clothes, and MISTRESS PAGE.

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.ab: Come, Mother Prat; come, give me your hand.

sp.speaker: Ford
sp.ab: I'll prat her.
Out of my door, you witch, you rag, you baggage,
you polecat, you ronyon! out, out! I'll conjure you,
I'll fortune-tell you.

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.ab: Are you not ashamed? I think you have killed the poor
woman.

sp.speaker: Mistress Ford
sp.ab: Nay, he will do it. 'Tis a goodly credit for you

sp.speaker: Ford
sp.ab: Hang her, witch!

sp.speaker: Evans
sp.ab: By yea and no, I think the 'oman is a witch
indeed: I like not when a 'oman has a great peard; I
spy a great peard under his muffler.

sp.speaker: Ford
sp.ab: Will you follow, gentlemen? I beseech you, follow;
see but the issue of my jealousy: if I cry out
thus upon no trail, never trust me when I open again.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.ab: Let's obey his humour a little further: come,
gentlemen.
sp.stage: Exeunt Ford, Page, Shal., Caius, and Evans.

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.ab: Trust me, he beat him most pitifully.

sp.speaker: Mistress Ford
sp.ab: Nay, by the mass, that he did not; he beat him most
unpitifully, methought.

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.ab: I'll have the cudgel hallowed and hung o'er the altar;
it hath done meritorious service.

sp.speaker: Mistress Ford
sp.ab: What think you? may we, with the warrant of
womanhood and the witness of a good conscience, pursue
him with any further revenge?

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.ab: The spirit of wantonness is, sure, scared out of
him: if the devil have him not in fee-simple,
with fine and recovery, he will never, I think, in the
way of waste, attempt us again.

sp.speaker: Mistress Ford
sp.ab: Shall we tell our husbands how we have served him?

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.ab: Yes, by all means; if it be but to scrape the
figures out of your husband's brains. If they
can find in their hearts the poor unvirtuous fat
knight shall be any further afflicted, we two will
still be the ministers.

sp.speaker: Mistress Ford
sp.ab: I'll warrant they'll have him publicly shamed:
and methinks there would be no period to the jest,
should he not be publicly shamed.

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.ab: Come, to the forge with it then; shape it: I would not
have things cool.

div.head: Act 4, Scene 3
div.stage: A room in the Garter Inn.

sp.speaker: Bardolph
sp.ab: Sir, the Germans desire to have three of your
horses: the duke himself will be to-morrow at court,
and they are going to meet him.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.ab: What duke should that be comes so secretly? I
hear not of him in the court. Let me speak with the
gentlemen: they speak English?

sp.speaker: Bardolph
sp.ab: Ay, sir; I'll call them to you.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.ab: They shall have my horses; but I'll make them
pay; I'll sauce them: they have had my house a
week at command; I have turned away my other guests:
they must come off; I'll sauce them. Come.

div.head: Act 4, Scene 4
div.stage: Enter PAGE, FORD, MISTRESS PAGE, MISTRESS FORD, and SIR HUGH EVANS.

sp.speaker: Evans
sp.ab: 'Tis one of the best discretions of a 'oman as ever I
did look upon.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.ab: And did he send you both these letters at an instant?

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.ab: Within a quarter of an hour.

sp.speaker: Ford
sp.l: Pardon me, wife. Henceforth do what thou wilt;
I rather will suspect the sun with cold
Than thee with wantonness: now doth thy honour stand,
In him that was of late an heretic,
As firm as faith.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: 'Tis well, 'tis well; no more:
Be not as extreme in submission
As in offence.
But let our plot go forward: let our wives
Yet once again, to make us public sport,
Appoint a meeting with this old fat fellow,
Where we may take him and disgrace him for it.

sp.speaker: Ford
sp.l: There is no better way than that they spoke of.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.ab: How? to send him word they'll meet him in the park at
midnight? Fie, fie! he'll never come.

sp.speaker: Evans
sp.ab: You say he has been thrown in the rivers and has
been grievously peaten as an old 'oman: methinks
there should be terrors in him that he should
not come; methinks his flesh is punished, he shall
have no desires.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.ab: So think I too.

sp.speaker: Mistress Ford
sp.l: Devise but how you'll use him when he comes,
And let us two devise to bring him thither.

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.l: There is an old tale goes that Herne the hunter,
Sometime a keeper here in Windsor forest,
Doth all the winter-time, at still midnight,
Walk round about an oak, with great ragged horns;
And there he blasts the tree and takes the cattle
And makes milch-kine yield blood and shakes a chain
In a most hideous and dreadful manner:
You have heard of such a spirit, and well you know
The superstitious idle-headed eld
Received and did deliver to our age
This tale of Herne the hunter for a truth.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: Why, yet there want not many that do fear
In deep of night to walk by this Herne's oak:
But what of this?

sp.speaker: Mistress Ford
sp.l: Marry, this is our device;
That Falstaff at that oak shall meet with us.
Disguised like Herne, with huge horns on his head.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: Well, let it not be doubted but he'll come:
And in this shape when you have brought him thither,
What shall be done with him? what is your plot?

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.l: That likewise have we thought upon, and thus:
Nan Page my daughter and my little son
And three or four more of their growth we'll dress
Like urchins, ouphes and fairies, green and white,
With rounds of waxen tapers on their heads,
And rattles in their hands: upon a sudden,
As Falstaff, she and I, are newly met,
Let them from forth a sawpit rush at once
With some diffused song: upon their sight,
We two in great amazedness will fly:
Then let them all encircle him about
And, fairy-like, to pinch the unclean knight,
And ask him why, that hour of fairy revel,
In their so sacred paths he dares to tread
In shape profane.

sp.speaker: Mistress Ford
sp.l: And till he tell the truth,
Let the supposed fairies pinch him sound
And burn him with their tapers.

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.l: The truth being known,
We'll all present ourselves, dis-horn the spirit,
And mock him home to Windsor.

sp.speaker: Ford
sp.l: The children must
Be practised well to this, or they'll ne'er do't.

sp.speaker: Evans
sp.ab: I will teach the children their behaviours; and
I will be like a jackanapes also, to burn the knight
with my taber.

sp.speaker: Ford
sp.ab: That will be excellent. I'll go buy them vizards.

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.l: My Nan shall be the queen of all the fairies,
Finely attired in a robe of white.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: That silk will I go buy. Aside
And in that time
Shall Master Slender steal my Nan away
And marry her at Eton. Go send to Falstaff straight.

sp.speaker: Ford
sp.l: Nay, I'll to him again in name of Brook:
He'll tell me all his purpose: sure, he'll come.

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.l: Fear not you that. Go get us properties
And tricking for our fairies.

sp.speaker: Evans
sp.ab: Let us about it: it is admirable pleasures and fery
honest knaveries.

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.l: Go, Mistress Ford,
Send quickly to Sir John, to know his mind. Exit Mrs. Ford.
I'll to the doctor: he hath my good will.
And none but he, to marry with Nan Page.
That Slender, though well landed, is an idiot;
And he my husband best of all affects.
The doctor is well moneyed and his friends
Potent at court: he, none but he, shall have her,
Though twenty thousand worthier come to crave her. Exit.

div.head: Act 4, Scene 5
div.stage: A room in the Garter Inn.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.ab: What wouldst thou have, boor? what, thick-skin? speak,
breathe, discuss; brief, short, quick, snap.

sp.speaker: Simple
sp.ab: Marry, sir, I come to speak with Sir John Falstaff
from Master Slender.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.ab: There's his chamber, his house, his castle, his
standing-bed and truckle-bed; 'tis painted about
with the story of the Prodigal, fresh and new.
Go knock and call; he'll speak like an
Anthropophaginian unto thee: knock, I say.

sp.speaker: Simple
sp.ab: There's an old woman, a fat woman, gone up into
his chamber. I'll be so bold as stay, sir, till she
come down; I come to speak with her, indeed.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.ab: Ha! a fat woman! the knight may be robbed; I'll
call. Bully-knight! bully Sir John! speak from
thy lungs military: art thou there? it is thine host,
thine Ephesian, calls.

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: How now, mine host!

sp.speaker: Host
sp.ab: Here's a Bohemian-Tartar tarries the coming down
of thy fat woman. Let her descend, bully, let
her descend; my chambers are honourable: fie! privacy?
fie!

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: There was, mine host, an old fat woman even now with
me! but she's gone.

sp.speaker: Simple
sp.ab: Pray you, sir, was't not the wise woman of Brentford?

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: Ay, marry, was it, mussel-shell: what would you with
her?

sp.speaker: Simple
sp.ab: My master, sir, my Master Slender, sent to her,
seeing her go thorough the streets, to know, sir,
whether one Nym, sir, that beguiled him of a chain,
had the chain or no.

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: I spake with the old woman about it.

sp.speaker: Simple
sp.ab: And what says she, I pray, sir?

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: Marry, she says that the very same man that
beguiled Master Slender of his chain cozened him of
it.

sp.speaker: Simple
sp.ab: I would I could have spoken with the woman herself;
I had other things to have spoken with her too from
him.

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: What are they? let us know.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.ab: Ay, come; quick.

sp.speaker: Simple
sp.ab: I may not conceal them, sir.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.ab: Conceal them, or thou diest.

sp.speaker: Simple
sp.ab: Why, sir, they were nothing but about Mistress
Anne Page; to know if it were my master's fortune to
have her or no.

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: 'Tis, 'tis his fortune.

sp.speaker: Simple
sp.ab: What, sir?

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: To have her, or no. Go; say the woman told me so.

sp.speaker: Simple
sp.ab: May I be bold to say so, sir?

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: Ay, sir; like who more bold.

sp.speaker: Simple
sp.ab: I thank your worship: I shall make my master glad with
these tidings.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.ab: Thou art clerkly, thou art clerkly, Sir John. Was
there a wise woman with thee?

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: Ay, that there was, mine host; one that hath
taught me more wit than ever I learned before in
my life; and I paid nothing for it neither, but was
paid for my learning.

sp.speaker: Bardolph
sp.ab: Out, alas, sir! cozenage, mere cozenage!

sp.speaker: Host
sp.ab: Where be my horses? speak well of them, varletto.

sp.speaker: Bardolph
sp.ab: Run away with the cozeners; for so soon as I came
beyond Eton, they threw me off from behind one
of them, in a slough of mire; and set spurs and
away, like three German devils, three Doctor
Faustuses.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.ab: They are gone but to meet the duke, villain: do not
say they be fled; Germans are honest men.

sp.speaker: Evans
sp.ab: Where is mine host?

sp.speaker: Host
sp.ab: What is the matter, sir?

sp.speaker: Evans
sp.ab: Have a care of your entertainments: there is a
friend of mine come to town, tells me there is
three cozen-germans that has cozened all the
hosts of Readins, of Maidenhead, of Colebrook,
of horses and money. I tell you for good will,
look you: you are wise and full of gibes and
vlouting-stocks, and 'tis not convenient you should be
cozened. Fare you well.

sp.speaker: Caius
sp.ab: Vere is mine host de Jarteer?

sp.speaker: Host
sp.ab: Here, master doctor, in perplexity and doubtful
dilemma.

sp.speaker: Caius
sp.ab: I cannot tell vat is dat: but it is tell-a me
dat you make grand preparation for a duke de
Jamany: by my trot, dere is no duke that the
court is know to come. I tell you for good will:
adieu.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.ab: Hue and cry, villain, go! Assist me, knight, I
am undone! Fly, run, hue and cry, villain! I am
undone!

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: I would all the world might be cozened; for I
have been cozened and beaten too. If it should
come to the ear of the court, how I have been
transformed and how my transformation hath been
washed and cudgelled, they would melt me out of
my fat drop by drop and liquor fishermen's boots
with me: I warrant they would whip me with their
fine wits till I were as crestfallen as a dried
pear. I never prospered since I forswore myself
at primero. Well, if my wind were but long enough
to say my prayers, I would repent.
Now, whence come you?

sp.speaker: Quickly
sp.ab: From the two parties, forsooth.

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: The devil take one party and his dam the other!
and so they shall be both bestowed. I have suffered
more for their sakes, more than the villainous
inconstancy of man's disposition is able to bear.

sp.speaker: Quickly
sp.ab: And have not they suffered? Yes, I warrant;
speciously one of them; Mistress Ford, good heart,
is beaten black and blue, that you cannot see a white
spot about her.

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: What tellest thou me of black and blue? I was
beaten myself into all the colours of the rainbow;
and I was like to be apprehended for the witch
of Brentford: but that my admirable dexterity of
wit, my counterfeiting the action of an old woman,
delivered me, the knave constable had set me i' the
stocks, i' the common stocks, for a witch.

sp.speaker: Quickly
sp.ab: Sir, let me speak with you in your chamber: you
shall hear how things go; and, I warrant, to your
content. Here is a letter will say somewhat. Good
hearts, what ado here is to bring you together!
Sure, one of you does not serve heaven well, that you
are so crossed.

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: Come up into my chamber.

div.head: Act 4, Scene 6
div.stage: Another room in the Garter Inn.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.ab: Master Fenton, talk not to me; my mind is heavy: I
will give over all.

sp.speaker: Fenton
sp.l: Yet hear me speak. Assist me in my purpose,
And, as I am a gentleman, I'll give thee
A hundred pound in gold more than your loss.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.ab: I will hear you, Master Fenton; and I will at the
least keep your counsel.

sp.speaker: Fenton
sp.l: From time to time I have acquainted you
With the dear love I bear to fair Anne Page;
Who mutually hath answered my affection,
So far forth as herself might be her chooser,
Even to my wish: I have a letter from her
Of such contents as you will wonder at;
The mirth whereof so larded with my matter,
That neither singly can be manifested,
Without the show of both; fat Falstaff
Hath a great scene: the image of the jest
I'll show you here at large. Hark, good mine host.
To-night at Herne's oak, just 'twixt twelve and one,
Must my sweet Nan present the Fairy Queen;
The purpose why, is here: in which disguise,
While other jests are something rank on foot,
Her father hath commanded her to slip
Away with Slender and with him at Eton
Immediately to marry: she hath consented:
Now, sir,
Her mother, even strong against that match
And firm for Doctor Caius, hath appointed
That he shall likewise shuffle her away,
While other sports are tasking of their minds,
And at the deanery, where a priest attends,
Straight marry her: to this her mother's plot
She seemingly obedient likewise hath
Made promise to the doctor. Now, thus it rests:
Her father means she shall be all in white,
And in that habit, when Slender sees his time
To take her by the hand and bid her go,
She shall go with him: her mother hath intended,
The better to denote her to the doctor,
For they must all be masked and vizarded,
That quaint in green she shall be loose enrobed,
With ribands pendent, flaring 'bout her head:
And when the doctor spies his vantage ripe,
To pinch her by the hand, and, on that token,
The maid hath given consent to go with him.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: Which means she to deceive, father or mother?

sp.speaker: Fenton
sp.l: Both, my good host, to go along with me:
And here it rests, that you'll procure the vicar
To stay for me at church 'twixt twelve and one,
And, in the lawful name of marrying,
To give our hearts united ceremony.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: Well, husband your device; I'll to the vicar:
Bring you the maid, you shall not lack a priest.

sp.speaker: Fenton
sp.l: So shall I evermore be bound to thee;
Besides, I'll make a present recompense. Exeunt.

div.head: Act 5, Scene 1
div.stage: A room in the Garter Inn.

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: Prithee, no more prattling; go, I'll hold. This
is the third time; I hope good luck lies in odd
numbers. Away! go. They say there is divinity in
odd numbers, either in nativity, chance, or death.
Away!

sp.speaker: Quickly
sp.ab: I'll provide you a chain; and I'll do what I can to
get you a pair of horns.

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: Away, I say; time wears: hold up your head, and
mince.
How now, Master Brook! Master Brook, the matter
will be known to-night, or never. Be you in the
Park about midnight, at Herne's oak, and you shall see
wonders.

sp.speaker: Ford
sp.ab: Went you not to her yesterday, sir, as you told me you
had appointed?

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: I went to her, Master Brook, as you see, like a
poor old man: but I came from her, Master Brook,
like a poor old woman. That same knave Ford, her
husband, hath the finest mad devil of jealousy
in him, Master Brook, that ever governed frenzy.
I will tell you: he beat me grievously, in the
shape of a woman; for in the shape of man, Master
Brook, I fear not Goliath with a weaver's beam;
because I know also life is a shuttle. I am in
haste; go along with me; I'll tell you all, Master
Brook. Since I plucked geese, played truant and
whipped top, I knew not what 'twas to be beaten
till lately. Follow me: I'll tell you strange
things of this knave Ford, on whom to-night I
will be revenged, and I will deliver his wife
into your hand. Follow. Strange things in hand, Master
Brook! Follow.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.ab: Come, come; we'll couch i' the castle-ditch till
we see the light of our fairies, Remember, son
Slender, my daughter.

sp.speaker: Slender
sp.ab: Ay, forsooth; I have spoke with her and we have
a nay-word how to know one another: I come to
her in white, and cry “mum;” she cries “budget;” and
by that we know one another.

sp.speaker: Shallow
sp.ab: That's good too: but what needs either your “mum”
or her “budget?” the white will decipher her well
enough. It hath struck ten o'clock.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.ab: The night is dark; light and spirits will become
it well. Heaven prosper our sport! No man means
evil but the devil, and we shall know him by his
horns. Let's away; follow me.

div.head: Act 5, Scene 3
div.stage: A street leading to the Park.
Enter MISTRESS PAGE, MISTRESS FORD, and DOCTOR CAIUS.

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.ab: Master doctor, my daughter is in green: when you
see your time, take her by the hand, away with
her to the deanery, and dispatch it quickly. Go before
into the Park: we two must go together.

sp.speaker: Caius
sp.ab: I know vat I have to do. Adieu.

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.ab: Fare you well, sir.
My husband will not rejoice so much at the abuse
of Falstaff as he will chafe at the doctor's
marrying my daughter: but 'tis no matter; better a
little chiding than a great deal of heart-break.

sp.speaker: Mistress Ford
sp.ab: Where is Nan now and her troop of fairies, and the
Welsh devil Hugh?

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.ab: They are all couched in a pit hard by Herne's
oak, with obscured lights; which, at the very
instant of Falstaff's and our meeting, they will at
once display to the night.

sp.speaker: Mistress Ford
sp.ab: That cannot choose but amaze him.

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.ab: If he be not amazed, he will be mocked; if he be
amazed, he will every way be mocked.

sp.speaker: Mistress Ford
sp.ab: We'll betray him finely.

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.l: Against such lewdsters and their lechery
Those that betray them do no treachery.

sp.speaker: Mistress Ford
sp.ab: The hour draws on. To the oak, to the oak!

div.head: Act 5, Scene 4
div.stage: Enter SIR HUGH EVANS, disguised, with others as Fairies.

sp.speaker: Evans
sp.ab: Trib, trib, fairies; come; and remember your
parts: be pold, I pray you; follow me into the
pit; and when I give the watch-'ords, do as I pid you:
come, come; trib, trib.

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: The Windsor bell hath struck twelve; the minute
draws on. Now, the hot-blooded gods assist me!
Remember, Jove, thou wast a bull for thy Europa;
love set on thy horns. O powerful love! that, in
some respects, makes a beast a man, in some other,
a man a beast. You were also, Jupiter, a swan
for the love of Leda. O omnipotent Love! how near
the god drew to the complexion of a goose! A
fault done first in the form of a beast. O Jove,
a beastly fault! And then another fault in the
semblance of a fowl; think on't, Jove; a foul
fault! When gods have hot backs, what shall poor
men do? For me, I am here a Windsor stag; and
the fattest, I think, i' the forest. Send me a
cool rut-time, Jove, or who can blame me to piss my
tallow? Who comes here? my doe?
sp.stage: Enter MISTRESS FORD and MISTRESS PAGE.

sp.speaker: Mistress Ford
sp.ab: Sir John! art thou there, my deer? my male deer?

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: My doe with the black scut! Let the sky rain
potatoes; let it thunder to the tune of Greensleeves,
hail kissing-comfits and snow eringoes; let there come
a tempest of provocation, I will shelter me here.

sp.speaker: Mistress Ford
sp.ab: Mistress Page is come with me, sweet heart.

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: Divide me like a bribed-buck, each a haunch: I
will keep my sides to myself, my shoulders for
the fellow of this walk, and my horns I bequeath
your husbands. Am I a woodman, ha? Speak I like
Herne the hunter? Why, now is Cupid a child of
conscience; he makes restitution. As I am a true
spirit, welcome!

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.ab: Alas, what noise?

sp.speaker: Mistress Ford
sp.ab: Heaven forgive our sins!

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: What should this be?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Page and Mrs. Ford
sp.ab: Away, away!

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: I think the devil will not have me damned, lest
the oil that's in me should set hell on fire; he would
never else cross me thus.
sp.stage: Enter SIR HUGH EVANS, disguised as before; PISTOL, as Hobgoblin; MISTRESS QUICKLY, ANNE PAGE, and others, as Fairies, with tapers.

sp.speaker: Quickly
sp.l: Fairies, black, grey, green, and white,
You moonshine revellers, and shades of night,
You orphan heirs of fixed destiny,
Attend your office and your quality.
Crier Hobgoblin, make the fairy oyes.

sp.speaker: Pistol
sp.l: Elves, list your names; silence, you airy toys.
Cricket, to Windsor chimneys shalt thou leap:
Where fires thou find'st unraked and hearths unswept,
There pinch the maids as blue as bilberry:
Our radiant queen hates sluts and sluttery.

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.l: They are fairies; he that speaks to them shall die:
I'll wink and couch: no man their works must eye. Lies down upon his face.

sp.speaker: Evans
sp.l: Where's Bede? Go you, and where you find a maid
That, ere she sleep, has thrice her prayers said,
Raise up the organs of her fantasy;
Sleep she as sound as careless infancy:
But those as sleep and think not on their sins,
Pinch them, arms, legs, backs, shoulders, sides and shins.

sp.speaker: Quickly
sp.l: About, about;
Search Windsor Castle, elves, within and out:
Strew good luck, ouphes, on every sacred room:
That it may stand till the perpetual doom,
In state as wholesome as in state 'tis fit,
Worthy the owner, and the owner it.
The several chairs of order look you scour
With juice of balm and every precious flower:
Each fair instalment, coat, and several crest,
With loyal blazon, evermore be blest!
And nightly, meadow-fairies, look you sing,
Like to the Garter's compass, in a ring:
The expressure that it bears, green let it be,
More fertile-fresh than all the field to see;
And “Honi soit qui mal y pense” write
In emerald tufts, flowers purple, blue, and white;
Like sapphire, pearl and rich embroidery,
Buckled below fair knighthood's bending knee:
Fairies use flowers for their charactery.
Away; disperse: but till 'tis one o'clock,
Our dance of custom round about the oak
Of Herne the hunter, let us not forget.

sp.speaker: Evans
sp.l: Pray you, lock hand in hand; yourselves in order set;
And twenty glow-worms shall our lanterns be,
To guide our measure round about the tree.
But, stay; I smell a man of middle-earth.

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: Heavens defend me from that Welsh fairy, lest he
transform me to a piece of cheese!

sp.speaker: Pistol
sp.l: Vile worm, thou wast o'erlooked even in thy birth.

sp.speaker: Quickly
sp.l: With trial-fire touch me his finger-end:
If he be chaste, the flame will back descend
And turn him to no pain; but if he start,
It is the flesh of a corrupted heart.

sp.speaker: Pistol
sp.l: A trial, come.

sp.speaker: Evans
sp.l: Come, will this wood take fire? They burn him with their tapers.

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: O, O, O!

sp.speaker: Quickly
sp.l: Corrupt, corrupt, and tainted in desire!
About him, fairies; sing a scornful rhyme;
And, as you trip, still pinch him to your time.

lg.l: Lust is but a bloody fire,
Fed in heart, whose flames aspire
As thoughts do blow them, higher and higher.
Pinch him, and burn him, and turn him about,
Till candles and starlight and moonshine be out.

sp.stage: During this song they pinch FALSTAFF. DOCTOR CAIUS comes one way, and steals away a boy in green; SLENDER another way, and takes off a boy in white; and FENTON comes, and steals away MRS ANNE PAGE. A noise of hunting is heard within. All the Fairies run away. FALSTAFF pulls off his buck's head, and rises.
Enter PAGE, FORD, MISTRESS PAGE and MISTRESS FORD.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: Nay, do not fly; I think we have watched you now:
Will none but Herne the hunter serve your turn?

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.l: I pray you, come, hold up the jest no higher.
Now, good Sir John, how like you Windsor wives?
See you these, husband? do not these fair yokes
Become the forest better than the town?

sp.speaker: Ford
sp.ab: Now, sir, who's a cuckold now? Master Brook,
Falstaff's a knave, a cuckoldly knave; here are
his horns, Master Brook: and, Master Brook, he
hath enjoyed nothing of Ford's but his buck-basket,
his cudgel, and twenty pounds of money, which
must be paid to Master Brook; his horses are arrested
for it, Master Brook.

sp.speaker: Mistress Ford
sp.ab: Sir John, we have had ill luck; we could never
meet. I will never take you for my love again; but I
will always count you my deer.

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: I do begin to perceive that I am made an ass.

sp.speaker: Ford
sp.ab: Ay, and an ox too: both the proofs are extant.

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: And these are not fairies? I was three or four
times in the thought they were not fairies: and
yet the guiltiness of my mind, the sudden surprise
of my powers, drove the grossness of the foppery
into a received belief, in despite of the teeth
of all rhyme and reason, that they were fairies.
See now how wit may be made a Jack-a-Lent, when 'tis
upon ill employment!

sp.speaker: Evans
sp.ab: Sir John Falstaff, serve Got, and leave your desires,
and fairies will not pinse you.

sp.speaker: Ford
sp.ab: Well, said, fairy Hugh.

sp.speaker: Evans
sp.ab: And leave you your jealousies too, I pray you.

sp.speaker: Ford
sp.ab: I will never mistrust my wife again, till thou art
able to woo her in good English.

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: Have I laid my brain in the sun and dried it,
that it wants matter to prevent so gross o'erreaching
as this? Am I ridden with a Welsh goat too? shall
I have a coxcomb of frieze? 'Tis time I were choked
with a piece of toasted cheese.

sp.speaker: Evans
sp.ab: Seese is not good to give putter; your belly is all
putter.

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: “Seese” and “putter”! have I lived to stand at
the taunt of one that makes fritters of English?
This is enough to be the decay of lust and
late-walking through the realm.

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.ab: Why, Sir John, do you think, though we would have
thrust virtue out of our hearts by the head and
shoulders and have given ourselves without scruple
to hell, that ever the devil could have made you our
delight?

sp.speaker: Ford
sp.ab: What, a hodge-pudding? a bag of flax!

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.ab: A puffed man?

sp.speaker: Page
sp.ab: Old, cold, withered and of intolerable entrails?

sp.speaker: Ford
sp.ab: And one that is as slanderous as Satan?

sp.speaker: Page
sp.ab: And as poor as Job?

sp.speaker: Ford
sp.ab: And as wicked as his wife?

sp.speaker: Evans
sp.ab: And given to fornications, and to taverns and
sack and wine and metheglins, and to drinkings and
swearings and starings, pribbles and prabbles?

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: Well, I am your theme: you have the start of me;
I am dejected; I am not able to answer the Welsh
flannel: ignorance itself is a plummet o'er me: use me
as you will.

sp.speaker: Ford
sp.ab: Marry, sir, we'll bring you to Windsor, to one
Master Brook, that you have cozened of money, to
whom you should have been a pander: over and
above that you have suffered, I think to repay that
money will be a biting affliction.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.ab: Yet be cheerful, knight: thou shalt eat a posset
to-night at my house; where I will desire thee
to laugh at my wife, that now laughs at thee: tell her
Master Slender hath married her daughter.

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.ab: Doctors doubt that: if Anne Page be my daughter, she
is, by this, Doctor Caius' wife.

sp.speaker: Slender
sp.ab: Whoa, ho! ho, father Page!

sp.speaker: Page
sp.ab: Son, how now! how now, son! have you dispatched?

sp.speaker: Slender
sp.ab: Dispatched! I'll make the best in Gloucestershire know
on't; would I were hanged, la, else!

sp.speaker: Page
sp.ab: Of what, son?

sp.speaker: Slender
sp.ab: I came yonder at Eton to marry Mistress Anne
Page, and she's a great lubberly boy. If it had
not been i' the church, I would have swinged him,
or he should have swinged me. If I did not think
it had been Anne Page, would I might never stir — and
'tis a postmaster's boy.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.ab: Upon my life, then, you took the wrong.

sp.speaker: Slender
sp.ab: When need you tell me that? I think so, when I
took a boy for a girl. If I had been married to
him, for all he was in woman's apparel, I would not
have had him.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.ab: Why, this is your own folly. Did not I tell you how
you should know my daughter by her garments?

sp.speaker: Slender
sp.ab: I went to her in white, and cried “mum,” and she
cried “budget,” as Anne and I had appointed; and yet
it was not Anne, but a postmaster's boy.

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.ab: Good George, be not angry: I knew of your purpose;
turned my daughter into green; and, indeed, she
is now with the doctor at the deanery, and there
married.

sp.speaker: Caius
sp.ab: Vere is Mistress Page? By gar, I am cozened: I
ha' married un garçon, a boy; un paysan, by gar, a
boy; it is not Anne Page: by gar, I am cozened.

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.ab: Why, did you take her in green?

sp.speaker: Caius
sp.ab: Ay, by gar, and 'tis a boy: by gar, I'll raise all
Windsor.

sp.speaker: Ford
sp.ab: This is strange. Who hath got the right Anne?

sp.speaker: Page
sp.ab: My heart misgives me: here comes Master Fenton.
How now, Master Fenton!

sp.speaker: Anne
sp.l: Pardon, good father! good my mother, pardon!

sp.speaker: Page
sp.ab: Now, mistress, how chance you went not with Master
Slender?

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.l: Why went you not with master doctor, maid?

sp.speaker: Fenton
sp.l: You do amaze her: hear the truth of it.
You would have married her most shamefully,
Where there was no proportion held in love.
The truth is, she and I, long since contracted,
Are now so sure that nothing can dissolve us.
The offence is holy that she hath committed;
And this deceit loses the name of craft,
Of disobedience, or unduteous title,
Since therein she doth evitate and shun
A thousand irreligious cursed hours,
Which forced marriage would have brought upon her.

sp.speaker: Ford
sp.l: Stand not amazed; here is no remedy:
In love the heavens themselves do guide the state;
Money buys lands, and wives are sold by fate.

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.ab: I am glad, though you have ta'en a special stand to
strike at me, that your arrow hath glanced.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: Well, what remedy? Fenton, heaven give thee joy!
“What cannot be eschewed must be embraced.

sp.speaker: Falstaff
sp.l: When night-dogs run, all sorts of deer are chased.

sp.speaker: Mistress Page
sp.l: Well, I will muse no further, Master Fenton,
Heaven give you many, many merry days!
Good husband, let us every one go home,
And laugh this sport o'er by a country fire;
Sir John and all.

sp.speaker: Ford
sp.l: Let it be so, Sir John,
To Master Brook you yet shall hold your word;
For he to-night shall lie with Mistress Ford. Exeunt.
